reviewText:
My wife has played through every race/ class combination possible, hence the 1300+ hours on record.  She has replayed the dwarf and human noble origins repeatedely just to know all possible outcomes (her favorite seems to be a dwarf rogue).  She is so good at playing the game she can run through it up to the final battle over a weekend (friday night, saturday, done sunday noon)
i was only able to write this review because she is at work.

...I miss my wife, can i have her back yet?

I guess i should recommend it because she plays it so voraciously?

EDIT: 4/8/15: HOLY FRAK PEOPLE! :D
for those of you thave have commented:
Yes the wife thinks i am like Alistair sometimes
Yes i have a beard
Yes she slays the dragons in the family...so far... but I am slowly catching up. (well she doesn't slay them directly per se, but she sets up the dragon to be slain by some warrior/fighter, typically Aveline, Fenris, or Iron Bull)

DA 2 was just as time consuming as DA: O (but with only 700-ish hours gameplay over 2014; less choices with char-gen means less replayability for her, only 6-8 characters made this time instead of 30-40)
DA: I ( which i just got for her in Feb. as a late X-mas gift) has totally consumed her time (AGAIN!) but with her new job she has only managed 300 hours (i estimate about 25 of it are my two characters) She is frustrated she cannot romance Varric
she loves Iron Bull  (who the hell doesn't he's got the best lines, along with Sera)


i told her no DLC until the main storyline is finished,  she gave me puppy dog eyes, i haven't cracked...yet...

I may be a bit biased but yes i do believe she is very awesome and I can geek out with her without her eyes glazing over, alternatively i dont Glaze-out either when she geeks out at me.

...so, hooray?  for totally life consuming video games...?

reviewText:
Disclaimer: This is my favorite game of all time, so I apologize for any obsessive fan-girling that may occur within this review.
tl;dr Pro's and Con's list at the bottom.

Theres so many things I could say about this game, I love it so much.  A majority of my time playing is on console, where I easily have 500+ hours, as well as every achievement in the game as well as additional content.  I'm not much of a reviewer (this being my first lengthy one), so to keep it simple I'll seperate it into sections.

Character Creation/Leveling-
There is a fair bit of customization when you create your character.  There are 3 races to choose from (Human, Dwarf, and Elf) which all give different bonus stats.  From there, you will pick your characters class (Warrior, Rogue, or Mage).  All of those classes expand at later levels, with your choice of sub-classes for each (unlocked at levels 7 and 14), which are unlocked by doing different things in the game, or learning them from certain characters.  So no, you aren't born with the ability to magically understand how to be a Bard, or a Templar, you need to actually be taught by someone, or learn the knowledge elsewhere.  Visual choices are alright, standard RPG things like different hair, different eyes, all of which will be covered by a helmet/cowl anyway no doubt.  Either way, you could always grab a mod or two for more character visuals, but I'll try to keep this review on the base game alone.  When you level up there are hefty decisions to be made.  Not only are there abilities for you to use in combat, there are also different abilties for out of combat purposes.  Are you going to put that point into your combat knowledge, unlocking the next tier of weapon abilites?  Or are you going to put it in lockpicking?  The next dungeon might have a door you can't quite pick yet.  Choose carefully...

Story-
The best thing about this game is the enthralling story!  From character creation, based on your race, and class even changes how your story begins.  Are you a human noble, living cozy in your castle?  Perhaps a dwarf whose fallen on hard times, and has gone down a life of crime.  Maybe even a mage, stripped from your family and sent off to the Circle of Magi to be watched by the Templars.  In most cases, different events from your Origin" story come back to either aid/hinder you based on how you handled them.  This game is full of heart-wrenching decisions

reviewText:
Words cannot describe how much I love this game, so allow me to describe it in words. Crafted by the same studio that has made some of my favorite RPGs of all time, Dragon Age answers the question of whether or not Bioware can create a compelling medieval fantasy RPG that isn't D&D based. The answer is a resounding yes. While containing many of the trappings of past RPGs like Neverwinter Nights and Baldur's Gate, Dragon Age works its own magic by offering three classes that can be customized by an almost infinite amount, six different origin stories for the player character, and doing away with the traditional good/evil morality mechanic in favor of one based on individual party approval or disapproval of your actions.

Each character in your party is believable and compelling, likeable for different reasons, and some can be romanced or change their outlook depending on how the story progresses. Every major questline can have different outcomes depending on player choices and it's this feeling of agency in the world that keeps the replay value in this game. Dragon Age has often been called a dark RPG and rightly so, as the story is much less straight forward than a typical RPG. Often you will find yourself having to deal with choices where there is no clear cut good" or "evil" outcome which is part of why player choice feels so meaningful.

And on top of all that
date: the game is a lot of fun. I remember the first time playing this game and saying "this is the game that Neverwinter Nights 2 should have been!" It still holds up
recommended: probably even more so against its sequel which in some ways is unfortunate. If you love western RPGs and loved the past work of Bioware
hoursPlayed: you will love this game. I give it two severed darkspawn thumbs way up!"

reviewText:
Dragon Age: Origins, debatably the last good game of Bioware's making, is a very intricate and detailed, although at sometimes cliche, foray into an action-adventure medieval setting.

Gameplay - Personally, this was my favorite part of the game. I loved the real time with pause system, and always have with other games such as KOTOR. My only complaint is that melee and ranged did not seem to shine as well as the magic system, especially with mana versus stamina. Often, I played as Morrigan instead of the Warden just because it was much more fun. The tactics system is well-done but the AI could use some more work, especially with rogues - even though they were supposed to go behind enemies for backstabs, more often than not, I had to do it myself. I feel as though the wide amount of abilities would easily allow for a just-as-fun second or third playthrough.

Story - The overarching storyline of the Blight was predictable, but I feel as though the game shines in the whole adventure there (as you don't directly" deal with the blight until the ending) was much better. The characters involved in the story were well-written and the many dialogue options involved with most major NPCs was refreshing

hoursPlayed: I really enjoyed the codex and each of its entries. The Fade was a unique concept which

reviewText: Dragons Age is well a put together RPG that will immerse you in the story and you will invest time in developing the characters that accompany you on your quest.  The biggest downside to the game is the story is tried, tired and done a thousand times over.  You the hero are on quest to destroy the dark spawn that is wreaking havoc on the land.  This being its biggest downfall does not make this a bad game at all.  I had over 70hours in one play through and with all the decision making you encounter this game will surely keep you amused for multiple plays.  One of the best combat systems I've seen  you can not only setup the AI to have your companions on the quest do what you like but you can fully take control of them which in my opinion is a huge advantage.  The combat system is a little bit of learning curve but once you get the hang of it you will love it and enjoy the simpleness of how your characters act and follow your directions in the heat of some best battles you will see in an RPG.  Bioware did an excellent job in creating a game you can fully plunge yourself into and get behind.

reviewText:
Reviews for the Deaf and Hard of Hearing
Overall Rating: 9/10
Gameplay Rating: 9/10
Accessibility Rating: 8/10

Overall rating is a combination of the gameplay (mechanics and story) and accessibility (how the game includes deaf/hoh gamers).

Overall GameplayDA:O's game format is very much in line with similar games by Bioware, ranging from Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic I/II, Mass Effect, etc.  If you're familiar with those games, you will understand the controls of this game.  If you haven't experienced those games, I would suggest each of them in addition to the Dragon Age line.

These tend to be very story-rich games, and DA:O is no exception.  Starting out, you create a character in a very scaled-back Dungeons and Dragons format.  You decide between male/female, elf/human/dwarf, and warrior/mage/rogue.  As you progress, there are further specializations you can pick up, such as a rogue bard or a mage healer.

At almost 30 hours of play, I am around 15-20% complete with the main storyline, so there's significant play time for the cost of the game.  Further, replay value comes from different character types, gender, and race, as well as modified slightly by the abilities of your character, such as intimidation or persuasion abilities.

I am enjoying this game and will continue to play it beyond one playthrough.

General AccessibilityDA:O primarily uses QWES to strafe/move and A/D to turn the camera.  I tend to hold right click to manipulate the camera and just use W to run forward.  The complexity of games like this require more keyboard use than an FPS, so different windows, HUDs, and menus can be accessed by various keys.  All keys can be rebound, making it a little more convenient for mobility-related issues.

In line with all games of this type from Bioware, the combat in the game can be paused so that you can issue orders to your party members.  In combat, you can pause as often as you need to, which helps balance the game experience out for all gamers, regardless of needs.

Subtitles & CaptionsSpeech is captioned in this game.  Important text is captioned so that you can read it readily and up-front and ambient speech (such as NPCs or banter between supporting characters in your party) shows up over their heads and can be read as you do other things.  Captions do not use color-coding, but conversations happen sequentially rather than simultaneously, and display the character on screen so you know who is talking.

One complaint is that these background conversations, captions may be missed entirely, depending on the camera angles.  These are usually interesting or funny conversations that help develop the characters and their relationships, but, more than once, I have only caught the end of them.  Part of the draw of games like this is getting immersed in the environment, but this is hard to do when the mechanics of the game do not permit it.

There is nothing in the game that requires being able to hear or hear well that I am aware of.

Chatting/CommunicatingDA:O is single-player.

No rating.

reviewText:
After owning this and playing the hell out of it on the PS3 I decided it was finally time to see how well the PC version was made and get a couple DLCs I hadn't played.

Right off the bat I noticed a massive difference from my console version in the load times. The PC version is a blink of an eye compared to my PS3 sounding like it was ready to take flight playing this with load times becoming increasingly annoying as you play through it.

The graphics and performance overall are far superior as well and the mouse/keyboard controls are nice. It does take a little bit of getting used to rotating the look with either the keyboard, or the mouse (you have to hold down the right button to look around), but you get used to it fast enough. Not to mention the ability to quicksave and not wait 5 seconds like on consoles.

As for the game itself, this is one of my all-time favorite RPGs. Mostly because I love the adult and mature content that it provides with the characters. No I'm not talkinng about sex, although you can hook up with other characters in your party and even have some grand old same sex encounters. The dialogue and writing in this game feels very realistic and not childish like most RPGs you will play. A lot of good dark humor as well as some smart interactions with the characters. This is what I love most about this series and what I loave about Bioware games in general like Mass Effect.

It is fun to mix and match your party as you walk around exploring as they all talk to each other while you walk and have different things to say based on who is in the group.

I would highly recommend this game to ALL RPG fans and would suggest buying the Ultimate Edition so that you can get all the DLC on Steam without the hassle of having to go through the Bioware website and getting shafted. The DLC is worth the few extra bucks for a completely new character (got this as a pre-order on PS3 I believe) that adds a lot of humor and their own character quests to the game.

The story is farily well done and has a lot of character quests like most Bioware games that addsdepth to your party. The DLCs expand on some of them and add even more story. Plus you get new items, skills, and characters that can be used in the main campaign.

The PC version also offers a decent modding community which can add a lot to the game, or take away some of the tedious things you dislike.

This game for me is an easy 9.5/10.

reviewText:
“Join us, brothers and sisters. Join us in the shadows, where we stand vigilant!”

Dragon Age: Origins is an excellent role-playing game with a truly epic campaign and great tactical gameplay.

It offers a rich and vivid world, loads of mature themes and memorable characters. The storytelling and dialogues are witty and engaging, the music is inspiring and you will be deeply involved in the compelling gameplay.

The different decisions and conversation options in combination with your individual character background allow you to proceed through the game in several ways resulting in a high replayability.

Amusing quotes:

“We now have a dog and Alistair is still the dumbest one in the party.”

“Let's show them our hearts, and then show them theirs.”

Trivia:

Dragon Age: Origins is often considered the spiritual successor to the Baldur's Gate series of games, which took place in the Forgotten Realms Campaign Setting of the Dungeons & Dragons franchise.

Achievements:

The game has no Steam achievements.

Chronology:

Dragon Age: Inquisition (PC)
Role-playing game
(Dark Fantasy) – 2014

Dragon Age 2 (PC)
Role-playing game
(Dark Fantasy) – 2011

Dragon Age: Origins (PC)

reviewText:
Dragon Age origins was No 1 and the best .... an absolutely brilliant game!
Six character backgrounds to choose to start with and all could be played through for the whole game. Several vastly different endings depending on choices made through the game. Fantastic and witty dialogue with all your companions that you were able to take with you on your adventure. Interactions between the companions that you had with you at random event places. Love scenes with characters that you had started to have a relationship with .... which needed to be be done slowly and well over a long time being aware of three way jealousies and confrontations with other companions.... Brilliantly worked out!

Massive Boss battles ... an AI system where you could set up how your companions would automatically react when certain conditions are met. Tough battles that you needed to be strategic about to survive... with a combination of four possible followers fighting with you and needing all the skills of magic, rogue and fighter to make it past all areas.

DA Origins had an expansion called Awakening to which you could take a save file from Origins to take you into it ... and you needed to as the enemies in Awakening were at that level and a new game started at awakening started with the same gear you would have had in Origins. So anyone wanting to battle level 30 enemies with a rusty dagger and a robe.... good luck.

The Awakening was a good addition a couple of your companions made the trip and could join you if you did all the right things. Certainly it is a smaller game than origins and a different one. But a worthy addition using the same game structure and similar dialogue ... although not as good as origins.

The Dragon Age 2 game actually doesn't really have anything to do with the first. Some of the lore is the same ... and from some of the decisions you made in DA O will be represented in some vague background stories. The dialogue was tweaked further but is became convoluted  ... but none of the characters really felt like someone I could relate to.
DA 2 had three chapters I completed the first and after 5 -6 tries eventually defeated the massive boss battle in the deep roads against the ARW (Ancient Rock Wraith) This battle was immense!

For that the resulting Treasure was a major Disappointment!!!! I had played as a mage up to that point and the robe in the treasure wasn't much different than anything previously. The only character who had decent armor was the dwarf (narrator of the game when cut scenes happened)  who's Armor leveled as he did ... so you would think this dwarf was the protagonist. Then you supposedly won a massive income from your trip into the deep roads such that you bought a house for your self and your companions ... (that I didn't care about) but had no money left, to even buy potions.

The only part of DA 2  that I did like was the combat! How they had you fight numerous enemies and the way spells and melee attacks worked was great. But hopeless story and characters that I couldn't care about .... and nothing to do with DA Origins at all very disappointing.

reviewText: Dragon Age: Origins is old-school. Before achievements and trophies, a role-player's greatest achievement was working the system to build the most broken, overpowered character possible within the constraints of whatever edition of Dungeons & Dragons the game was based on. Origins is a solitary experience; you'll isolate yourself from the outside world, staying up nights and well into the morning because when this game grabs you, it simply won't let go.\n\nThis is a game that's been in development for what seems like forever, and it shows. BioWare's own Mass Effect was far more visually impressive, particularly in the dialogue sequences, where Dragon Age's facial animations and character models can seem stiff and wooden. Then there's the odd decision to go so over-the-top with the blood. Blood plays an important role in the world's unique fiction, but watching your characters relay meaningful lines of speech while splashed with more blood than the prom scene in Carrie" borders on the ridiculous
date: robbing such scenes of any potential sense of gravitas.\n\nThat isn't to say that this is an ugly game
recommended: by any means. Dragon Age: Origins' landscapes and dungeon interiors are rife with detail and a joy to explore. Combat animations in particular are impressive
hoursPlayed: as your characters will set themselves before enemies and go through complex motions
voteText: with rogues jockeying for position to backstab and warriors forcefully slamming their shields into faces. Colorful kill animations result in dismemberments and decapitations
helpfulPercent: rewarding you for critical strikes in a far more memorable manner than just a bigger damage number. Then there's the sheer scale of this undertaking. You can easily log a hundred hours exploring every inch of this world
votesHelpful: with plenty of incentive to come back again to approach the tale of the Grey Warden from a new perspective and origin story.\n\nYour character's origin story
votesTotal: the first steps in your adventure
votesFunny: plays a significant role in how this tale plays out. The tropes of fantasy fiction lie intact
commentsCount: with Dwarves dwelling underground and elves living in the world's forests on the outskirts of human civilization

column17: with the nobility focusing on political advancement while the casteless underclass live in ghettos
column18: struggling to eke out a living as part of the criminal underbelly. Elves who live in human cities reside in closed-off alienages
column19: destined for a life of servitude to the human nobility. Magi live secluded lives of research and study in their towers under the constant watch of the order of Templars
column20: a religious sect tasked with ensuring that magic does not lead to demonic infestation.\n\nWhile your own story is important
column21: the companions that join you play an equally important role. The Grey Warden Alistair
column22: the witch of the wilds Morrigan
column23: and the mysterious minstrel Leliana are your primary romantic options and the game's main supporting characters
column24: though other characters like Sten
column26: are nearly as interesting. Even the dog companion is a full-fledged ally worthy of bringing along
column27: complete with his own inventory and unique abilities. The quality of the voice work ensures that you'll rarely skip through the frequent conversations and inter-party banter. You'll spend lots of time wading through interminably long conversations while getting to know the members of your party
column28: in an effort to improve their approval ratings.\n\nFans of Dungeons & Dragons-styled role-playing adventures may be annoyed that there are only three core character classes and three race options
column29: but there's remarkable depth to the character development system. Each class has a variety of talent options
column30: and four specializations to choose from: Warriors can go weapon and shield or two-handed
column31: Rogues can become archers or dual-wield

column33: riveting combat sequences where strategy and tactics win out.\n\nAgain
column34: it's the decisions that make Dragon Age: Origins such a thought-provoking experience. I've played through the game twice now and I still have trouble choosing which companions to take with me on any given adventure. The story has a way of dropping situations in your lap where any of a handful of different options seem viable
column35: with no clear-cut option standing out as the right one. This is due in part to Dragon Age: Origins' lack of a clearly defined moral alignment structure. Characters are generally complex
column36: defying the unrealistically simplistic labels of "good" and "evil
column37: and the game is the better for it.\n\nThere is so much more to Dragon Age: Origins I just don't have room to explain here. Simply know that there are tons of weapons and loot to find, craft, and coat with poison, thousands of quests to take on, storekeepers to intimidate, and NPCs to persuade. If you're a Western-style, fantasy RPG nut, or if you love a great tactical challenge, you simply can't go wrong with Dragon Age: Origins. BioWare has outdone itself once again.

reviewText: This is it, right here. This is the RPG to define all other RPGs. Dragon Age: Origins, is personally my favorite RPG of all time. Between the huge amount of hours that I have logged on Steam and the countless hours played on PS3, I have experienced pretty much all you can experience within the game. I guess you could say I'm kind of a big deal. Dragon Age: Origins is one of the best written RPGs ever made, showcasing BioWare at its finest. With a deep and intricate story, varied and memorable characters, and deep gameplay using the d20 system. If you like fantasy at all, then you will enjoy what this game has to offer.

reviewText:
AT A GLANCE(Full review follows below)

Game Name: Dragon Age: Origins
Original Release: 2010
Genre Tags: RPG; Strategy; Fantasy; Story-Rich; Epic
My Overall Grade: A+
Estimated Playtime (Campaign): 60-150 hours
Multiplayer Aspect: None
Recommended To: Established fans of the genre; Those intrigued by the genre; Strong narrative advocates; Game atmosphere connoisseurs; Epic RPG enthusiasts
REVIEWDragon Age: Origins is an immersive action/strategy RPG with a deep, intricate story and the potential for hundreds of gameplay hours.  If you like plunging yourself into truly epic RPGs which can keep you glued to your computer for days on end, this is one of the best games to play.

Right from the start, the massiveness of the game assaults you. Making your standard start-of-an-RPG choices of character race and class will determine which of six origin stories you will play through to open the game.  Each of these stories can take several hours to beat.  And if you are like me, you will need to play them all before deciding which character you will anoint the chosen one which you will play as for the entirety of the campaign.  Who you choose will also affect certain conversations and quests in the main part of the game.

Continuing with the theme of massiveness, the narrative and lore elements are truly epic and expansive. The main narrative is well written with great pacing, telling an interesting tale rooted in classic fantasy themes. The characters are diverse and interesting, and each one is given an actual presence in the world. And if you enjoy immersing yourself in the nuances of fantasy gameworlds, you will be pleased to know there is a plethora of lore and backstory. There is so much to learn about.

As for the gameworld: it is atmospheric and mystical. There is no gigantic overworld to freely traverse, however. But the locations that do exist are very well designed and are expressive of the setting. And the graphics succeed in painting the picture that is intended, even if they may fall behind the curve as this game begins to age.

The gameplay mechanics and the battle system are intricate and elaborate. On the higher difficulties, deep knowledge of interactive effects is necessary for tough battles. Luckily on the lower difficulties, you can get away with only a rudimentary understanding. But as you unlock new abilities and new characters who offer new playable classes, experimenting with different party combinations can help spice up the combat. For any game that lasts over 100 hours, that can be a welcome feature.

One of the headlining concepts at the heart of Dragon Age: Origins is the decision system. I alluded to this earlier when I mentioned the diverse origin stories. There are a multitude of decisions to be made throughout the game, most of which have some sort of impact on the gameworld— be it large or small. And to make it better, most of the decisions have no clear “right or wrong,” so you’ll really have to make choices (and not just choose what you know the game wants you to).

It is beginning to age, but true quality cannot easily be eroded by the sands of time. If you are a fan of truly epic RPGs, this one is a must-play for you. My only warning is that it is quite verbose and grand in scale, so if you are someone who easily loses interest then you may struggle with the sheer magnitude of the game.

Follow my curation page to see more of my recommendations!

reviewText:
From the brains of the guys and gals behind Baldur's Gate, Jade Empire, Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic and Mass Effect emerges this game - Dragon Age: Origins. BioWare certainly knows how to pull off a good RPG, they are clearly not afraid to implement whatever they please to make it a superb experience. Dragon Age: Origins is no different. The game is set in the fantasy world known as Ferelden. A land that for long has been safe from war and suffering and looks like your typical fantasy land with elves, dwarves, wizards, maidens and of course - Dragons.

The peace is not to last though, peace is a pretty bad setting to make a game in to be honest. A dark force gathers in the outskirts of the Kingdom and soon the faith of humanity (or what species have you) solely rests on your shoulders. In other words - like every single damn fantasy RPG out there. But hold your unicorns, that does not mean the game is bad does it? No! Making a game in the stereotypical RPG/Fantasy is never a bad thing. As long as it's up to standard with implemented unique features that successfully intertwine with a very good story.

BioWare themselves described the game as the spritual successor to Baldur's Gate, at least in the sense of the atmosphere and game setting. I have not played Baldur's Gate, so I can not answer to this. I can however say that the game reminds A lot of Mass Effect and Star Wars: KoTOR, combine that with the general fantasy setting (like Skyrim), some intriguing story and this game is set to blow your brains out.

My experience with this game has sadly been... shattered, though. I have throughout the years seriously tried to set my mind on RPG-mode, and just sink myself into this adventure. But I have only finished the game once, and have probably played the start 10 times. I am attracted by the setting and gameplay, but I always seem to end up forcing myself through the game, because I feel that the game MUST be good. Unlike with Mass Effect or any of the Elder Scrolls games for example, I pretty much ended up disliking the game because of my issue. I had the same problem with Bioshock, but this is just me, so it does not make the game any less good. You just have to crave for some RPG goodness, and not rush through it.

Just like most BioWare games, you are but one character in a squad/company, and most of the gameplay are dependent on this as a strategic mechanic. It is possible to just ignore the other characters in your company, but this would require your main character to completely carry every fight, which is not optimal. Again, as with all Fantasy RPGs, you get to pick a class; Warrior, Mage or Rogue and build your character from scratch. In Dragon Age you also get to pick race and background, giving even more options as well as unlocking different storylines. This is to make every playthrough a unique experience compared to the previous. Overall BioWare are known as masters at extensive and complex dialogues for their games, often to make you choose a dark or bright path and reflect your options into the upcoming events.

What I however Did enjoy about the game was the enormous background history to build the series on, the grim setting, the interactions between the main character and NPC characters, some adult scenery and romance interactions, the depiction of cracks in a fictional society that may or may not be referring to real life scenarios. As the majority of this game attract me I feel that it deserves a positive rating, even though I will probably not play it again due to lack of patience and time.

If you love BioWare's games, Fantasy RPG's and are ready to sacrifice dozens of hours for a grand adventure, then this game is likely to entertain.

reviewText:
Compelling, epic story. Great graphics (starting to look dated in '14 but still beautiful). Rich characters. Masterfully crafted ending. Solid gameplay. This game's got it all, and I insist that you give it a chance if you haven't already.

I've beaten this game more times than I care to admit on Origin and bought it here on steam just so I could uninstall Origin.

The only downside to this game, and yes there is one - is that once you finish it, you'll be left excited and drooling for its sequel... but we all know how that turned out. You'll be left with a craving which you will never be able to fill.

reviewText:
It's a good RPG with a very rich story and some interesting locations, but there's also a good amount of things that aren't that great.

The presentation is flawless. The locations have a nice amount of detail and all feel unique. The music is great and the voice acting ranges from solid to excellent.

The story will drag you in and give you many choices. There is a lot of flavour text to read and you can easily spend a couple of hours just wading through optional dialogue. There are also weaker quests and predictable subplots, but overall the story is good.

Now to the not so good things: The combat system isn't bad, but you'll struggle with it quite often due to it being kind of delayed. Which in harder fights were every second counts can be very annoying. The game isn't overly hard, but there are fights that will really drain your patience because they aren't exactly well balanced.

Next problem is the design of especially the later dungeons in the game. They are just stretched out way too much and filled with pointless time and resource consuming fights. In combination with the subpar combat system it's tedious to push through them.

Lastly I have to say that the setting couldn't be more generic. There's nothing in this game that you haven't seen before (maybe except for some demons), but overall it feels like the team had a lot of ideas about the story, but none about the background. This is just a minor complaint though.

I recommend the game, but mainly if you enjoy the story in a game more than actual gameplay.

Edit: I just finished the expansion (The Awakening) and found it important to add a few lines about it as well. One complain about the main game was that it wasn't original enough in terms of setting and I have to say that this expansion really does a good job at correcting that mistake. It's nowhere as obvious what's going on as in the main game and there are unique non-human villains this time. Also due to the shorter nature of the expansion the dungeons don't drag as much as in the main game. I really enjoyed the expansion and would even go as far as saying that it's slightly better than the main game. This is more about the overall gameplay and not about the story. If you want to play the game you should really get the ultimate edition to get the full experience.

reviewText:
Dragon Age: Origins is the best game I've ever played in terms of role-playing. The Origin story system allows you to create characters that feel unique every time, and make every playthrough completely different. The interactions between your character and your companions are incredibly complex and engaging, and allow you to really develop your character's personality. The storyline is very long yet entertaining, and gives you many options as to how to proceed through and eventually complete the game. Often times, there is no right decision, and your actions will have far reaching consequences, and will also affect your companions' opinion of you.

As for the gameplay, it is different to many RPGs in that it is very strategy based, and when playing on Normal or harder, you will have to actively manage all four members of your party in order to succeed. The combat can be very punishing and is perhaps too difficult, especially early in the game. Warriors, the front line of your party, will die very quickly without high stats and equipment. However, if you use your party's abilities well, and make good decisions as to which abilities you unlock, you should be alright.

The game is open world, though to travel between areas, you must watch your progress on a map. The textures of the NPCs are good enough that they don't affect immersion, yet many of the textures of the environment are rather low-res. However, the game is pretty old now so that is only to be expected. I did not find that it took away from my role-playing experience. The voice-acting is superb, and while like most games you get used to the same voice actors, each NPC does seem slightly different.

Overall, I would recommend this game to anyone, and putting in the hours to beat the storyline is extremely rewarding. The various expansions provide a significant late game, or you could just make a totally new character! Even after two playthroughs, the game says I have only completed 54% of the content. Buy this game!

Currently I have logged 313 hours onto this game and I find myself coninueing to enjoy it.

reviewText:
So in 2009, Bioware decided to return to its roots of making RPGs in the vein of Baldur's Gate with Dragon Age: Origins. What resulted is a very engaging and thrilling tale of a band of misfits that come together to defeat the evil Darkspawn and their leader, the Archdemon. I wholeheartedly can recommend it.

The story of Dragon Age is a pretty good one, with a good mix of political intrigue and dark fantasy themes. There is some really expansive lore in this game available for you to read in the codex, which would take you hours to read. I assure you, however, that reading all of it is worth it.

The party members are all unique characters, and well-written. Some would say a few are weaker than others as far as being interesting (looking at you, Sten), but they all have decent backstories and are really fun to hear banter between each other. That's another thing; the party banter is hilarious and worth stopping to listen to.

The combat in this game is beyond thrilling. You can pause combat at any time to issue orders to your four-member party, and after unpausing they will act out the order. You can play the game either in third-person or an isometric view. I prefer the isometric for tactical reasons and for that classic Baldur's Gate/Planescape feel. You can also set up tactics for your party members so that they will use certain items/abilities when a condition is met. This can get as in-depth as you like, and its one of the coolest features of the game in my humble opinion.

Graphically, the game doesn't look too bad for how old it is already, but there are texture mods to spice it up, if you're interested. Be aware, however, that this could cause stuterring due to the game engine not really liking textures being TOO large. Otherwise, the graphics are servicable, but nothing to write home about. I don't really care about them, but its up to you to decide whether or not they bother you.

tl;dr Dragon Age: Origins is a return to form for Bioware RPGs and a great 100-or-so-hour romp for RPG nerds like myself. Buy it if you want to experience one of the better games to come out in recent years. Its worth it. Good story, good characters, great game.

reviewText:
It’s not easy always being at the cutting edge, and that’s why I’ve decided to review this Dragon Age game, and not the new one which people are currently interested in.

DA:O is a few years old now, but it has taken a few attempts for me to actually stick with it, and it with me. Hence, tardy review. But, let me be clear, right off the bat. It’s as good as everybody said it was, all those years ago! Sure, it has a somewhat off-putting generic fantasy shell, and the designers needn’t have limited themselves to just four colours (brown, grey, green, and reddish-brown) when they were painting this grand adventure. You might say it’s more realistic but sod realism, this is a fantasy game, and it’s all a bit too “trad”, at least at first blush.

However, I can only speak personally. There are many people who adore trad fantasy and all its trappings, and who don’t like change. More power to them, but for me, at first glance, there doesn’t seem to a lot of originality here, in setting or theme. I persisted, peeled back those crusty brownish-grey outer layers, and found something truly engrossing. This game has a lot of humour, and a lot of heart.

When it was first released, there was a lot of buzz about DA:O being a spiritual successor to the Baldur’s Gate games, which meant there would be swords, dragons, magic, derring-do and loads of fighting. This is all true of DA:O. There was also a lot of hype for the “Origins” system, proudly displayed in the title, which meant that instead of having one single starting sequence (location, npcs, events) you’d have a different one based on your race and class. You might find yourself a poor elf in an alienage, forced to get by on your wits and the point of a knife, or a stalwart dwarven noble in a monumental underground palace, and all the intrigue that entails. Where you come from also affects how you’ll be perceived by party members and other important characters in the game. It was supposed to make you feel more of a connection to your character, and I think it really works and actually helps give the game a decent amount of replayability.

From my own experience the balance of the game is probably weighted about 60/40 in favour of combat over conversation, which is okay. It’s not great: there have been times when I’ve been exploring a temple or an underground cavern and become completely fatigued with having to fight the same enemies again and again, with the only difference being that this time it’s archers instead of mages standing at the back. It hasn’t happened often, though, and because the game is relatively free-form, you can always go and do something else. If you’re the type of player that prefers diplomacy over fistcuffery, beware: more often than not, quests end in big fights.

Combat takes place in real-time, but you can pause the game to issue commands, and watch them play out when you unpause. There are tons of spells and skills, so you’ll want to make sure to use the right ones at the right times. I’d say that on any difficulty above Easy, you will need to pause quite regularly and be prepared to micro-manage to some degree. The other option is setting up tactics for each party member, which are like little scripts for them to follow. You might set up your tank to immediately engage the strongest enemy, or tell your mage to cast an AoE if enemies are standing near to each other. This takes time to organise, and tactics which work for one fight may not do so well in another, but generally this feature will reduce busywork and it can be satisfying to spectate as your team dismantles the enemy without you lifting a finger.

Fights can get quite busy. You will almost always be assaulted by many foes, some up close and some at range, and there will be bursts of fire and magic bolts flying. It can be hard to keep track, so it’s a good thing the devs included a tactical camera. You can flick the mousewheel to pull the camera back into the ceiling, just far enough that you can see who is who and where people are positioned. It’s pretty useful, and entirely missing from the console versions. Pat yourself on the back for owning a PC.

I mentioned before that I’ve bounced off this game, and this has been because of difficulty spikes. Depending on in which order you choose to approach the three (or four, I forget) “main” quests in the game, you may find yourself running up against enemies which are too tough for you, or battles which seem to go on forever, where enemy waves continuously spawn. Case in point, Redcliffe, which Alistair, a party member, specifically advises you to tackle first of all. This questline is good fun, but very combat heavy and has a one particular fight where waves of enemies just keep on spawning, so you need to keep party members safe all the way through the fight. From a storytelling point of view it makes sense: Alistair cares for the Arl of Redcliffe, and can’t have known about the danger before telling you to go there. But as a player, it’s a harsh lesson to learn at an early point in the game. As I said, don’t be afraid to go and do something else if you keep getting hammered.

Will wrap up with the most positive points. The writing is frequently excellent, particularly with regards to the banter between party members. The lore is deep, and the in-game codex completely overflows with interesting entries to read about the history of the land, the people and the places. It looks good! Faces are a bit “uncanny valley” at times, but mostly well animated and  believable.

If you’re in the market for a deep and fairly complex RPG to sink your teeth into, then get Dragon Age: Inquisition. But, if you’re poor like me, get this one.

reviewText: Dragon Age: Origins is a spectacular edition to the fantasy genre. It has a lovely story of good vs. evil, and graces you with a lovely story with each waking. The companions, while not plentiful, are memorable. Each  one of them has a distinct personality, and react to different situations differently. Bioware has their trademark beautiful talking cutscenes, and depending on your group, and standing with them, they will jump into conversations on various occasions. The six varying ways to start the game adds a lot of diversity, and replayability for that matter. It's gameplay can be compared to WoW if you are familiar with it. A skill bar at the bottom for abilities and items, though a twist comes in. You have a party of four to control, you and three companions, and you have the ability to control each and every one. You gain even more control with the ability to pause the combat, and issues orders to be done when you unpause it. If you don't like strategizing, and have a console, you could pick it up on the Xbox or playstation for a more combat oriented gameplay.TL;DR, Overall, this game is a must-buy for anyone who enjoys the fantasy, spell-casting, and shield-bashing genre that this game falls under. In my honest opinion, this game is a 10/10. Great characters, good gameplay, and good story.

reviewText:
Dragon Age was my first real experience with a computer game. I saw someone else playing it and wanted to give it a go. I ended up buying a PS3 and the game on console and played it through from start to finish twice (that's over 200 hours of playtime right there). Starting an Origins game is a bit of commitment, often I lose track of what I was planning for a character if I stop playing them for a while, so I start over. Rinse and repeat.

At the time I can genuinely say that this game changed my life. How it holds up now is a bit harder to say for sure. I find the combat slow (which was great when I had never played a combat game before) and in fact the whole game is a bit on the slow side by today's standards, but if you can get past older graphics and a slow pace, I recommend giving it a go. Especially, when you can buy the whole lot on sale for so little.

It has romance, humour, friendship, betrayal and so much more. The lore of the Dragon Age universe is deep and there is plenty to read if you're interested in a world with a lot of depth. The main story arc remains the same no matter what you do - for the most part - but you can surely mess with a lot of people's lives along the way, including your own followers. Will they find happiness? Love? A horrible death? Sometimes they will even break your heart.

Also, there are 6 totally different starts to the game depending largely on race and class. If you find starting the game as a human noble a bit boring, try being a circle mage or a dwarven commoner or dwarven royalty or a city elf or a dalish elf. Each start is different. You will find yourself in a different location with a different tragedy establishing who you are. A few hours in all the stories converge to the main story arc, but you will never forget where you came from and where it placed you in the world. No amount of this is your backstory" can have the impact of experiencing it.

Even better is that you can import your save game into DA2 or use the Dragon Age Keep to recreate (or rewrite) your story for Inquisition and the choices you made will change both of those games in many small ways! You can have a continuous history over all three games. It's a beautiful thing.

As for the content packs
date: some have more in them than others. One of my favourites is The Darkspawn Chronicles. Have you ever wondered how the final battle of a game would go if you were playing as the enemy? It was awful
recommended: having to defeat my own beloved companions in the final battle
hoursPlayed: but also really interesting. There were cutscenes and all. I may have even cried a little.\n\nAwakenings starts to move more into the style of Dragon Age 2 and introduces a very important character or two. It's a fairly substantial bit of extra content

reviewText:
Take a fantasy novel, double it's length, throw in BioWare, and add a little EA meddling to make yet another Bioware classic.

There isn't a secret recipe for a good solid game. It's just a shame the pure ingredient called Bioware can't be found anymore. You always find it now tainted with EA.

While you will find this title to be well crafted, it's not for everyone. I had to get over my hate for the  fantasy genre, which wasn't easy. I'm glad that I did, as I would have missed out on yet another  Bioware classic. If you prefer running n' gunning, don't dream of playing this unless you can change your attitude. Sadly, many of the newer generation of PC gamers fall into the “action packed” trap, where they miss out on what makes a game – it's story. Characters take revenge, scheme behind your back, among other things.

Speaking of story, one of my teachers once told me that a good plot mixes together the right amounts of gore, sex, and humor. While you will find all three in Dragon Age: Origins, there isn't enough humor to lighten the load so to speak. You will find that the story simply drags on. I recommend playing in 1-3 hour sessions, otherwise you might just end up leaving such a great title in the dust. The “behind your back” conversations are a nice break as the maps can take a long time to explore.

It took me about 65 hours to play though once, not even completing every single minor side quest. Mass Effect 3 took 24, and the others in the series about 12-24. The store page lists 80 hours of gameplay, which seems about right. Many won't be able to withstand that long on one game since it feels like it just drags on. At the end of the day, if you can bear with it, you won't be disappointed.

The “Ultimate Edition” includes quite a few DLCs that I didn't end up using/playing. The original seems plenty long enough, but I don't think I will end up going back soon for “The Awakening” DLC. The game ends with a cliff hanger, which was obviously setup for the 2nd.

The joke with Mass Effect is that you should get an achievement for not getting laid. While some of you understand that joke and it being true for Mass Effect, it's not the same here. Dragon Age uses a scale from -100 to 100 (or what seems to be -100). If a party member's gauge is to low, they will leave you! Mass Effect uses a simple 1-5 scale, where “loyalty” is at 4, romance is declared at a 5, and save porting uses a special 6. All of that is of course hidden, but in Dragon Age it isn't. This newer and what some would call better “romance mechanic” makes it hard to understand. This isn't a real life simulator, but does a much better job then the “getting laid simulator” in the Mass Effect series. You can follow and please one individual, but then end up displeasing others severely – even if they aren't in your current party. Throw in the invisible “hardening” mechanic as well.. You will have to read the wiki to understand how complex the whole game is.

It's judgment time now. I think 91/100 is fair for the metascore, as long as you can overcome your hate for the fantasy genre (nudge nudge me), not enough “pew pew” (many young gamers) and understand or appreciate the mature subjects within the title.

So all in all, even with bugs in character's movement, old 2009 graphics, and a story that just seems to drag on, I can't stamp a great or terrible score. Playing quite a few other titles, and understanding who you need to be to enjoy this, I give this super long review a number for the game.

8.5/10

reviewText:
The following review will be my first impression of the game.
I bought the Ultimate Edition while it was on sale, and I definitely think I got more than my money's worth. In retrospect, I'd probably buy it for the normal price. Let me tell you why:

PROS
-In RPG's like Skyrim, ESO, and even Dragon Age Inquisition, I have a bad habit of skipping through dialouge. With this game, however, I found myself listening closely to every single cutscene. I started as a human rogue, so I'm not sure what the other origin stories are like.
-The combat is certainly interesting. It's not like the games ahead of this one. In fact, it reminded me very much of Runescape combat. You click on an enemy, and your player auto-attacks it. Of course, you can use your abilities. I have yet to explore the tactical combat system. I just don't like pausing the game to give orders, and it's working out fine for me.
-The character customization is decent. One benefit of playing on PC is the availability of mods. While I found the base hairstyles and facial features more than enough, there are some mods to add more choices if you're really invested in your character's appearance.
-The followers are full of personality, and you can romance some of them too.
-The dialouge options are great for roleplaying. Instead of the standard 2 choices of evil and good responses, there's four or so responses you can choose from to create a more in-depth personality for your character.

CONS:
-Don't be expecting amazing graphics. It's pretty standard, even on the highest setting.
-The movement system is clunky and weird to get used to at first. A and D keys turn the camera instead of the traditional strafing movements offered by newer games. If you hold down the right mouse button you can swivel the camera, which I found to be easier.

As someone who played Dragon Age 2 and Inquisition before visiting this game, I can say it's a completely different experience- in a good way. You cannot go wrong buying this game while it's on sale.

reviewText: I'm a grandmother and often simply cannot keep up with many of the fast paced action games out there. However, with the pause capability and the ability to move every character to where I want them is perfect for me. Also the fact it let's me make my own danged decisions counts as well (well most of them...there are some it steers me into without mercy). I admit that I usually play at normal with a few drops into casual which enables me to enjoy the game even more. The fact that I can do that is  a plus, instead of doing a battle over and over until I win  (not that I haven't done that) or worse, be forced to give up. This game is like immersing oneself into a rich story that one mostly controls. Not that fate won't have it's say now and again. A thing that is all to the good. Like the building games I adore, you place one brick after another, each time hoping it's the right brick, and watch your creation expand and grow. Don't get complacent though, as any of your bricks/comments can cause a totally unexpected reaction. I say go for it and enjoy!

reviewText:
I love this game.
There's not enough words describing how amazing this game actually is.
Game is basically old, but it doesn't even look like it's old, doesn't even play like it's old, doesn't even feel like it's old.
Basically the game is practically awesome and definitely worth buying the Ultimate Edition, because it comes with an amazing Extension pack which is called Dragon Age: Awakening, and it comes with around 10 DLC's which, believe me, bring A LOT more experience to the gameplay.
I bought the game recently for the PC version, but already finished the game on the ps3 version.
Gameplay is very unique, which brings a new aspect to the game.
Storyline is amazing, all the special effects and everything just make the game enjoyable as hell.

What I like about the game:

- The Gameplay (Controls and other technical things)

- The Storyline (You can basically choose from being a Human, to being an Elf, to being a Dwarf and each race comes with it's own story)
(I personally like Human race, because of all the armors you can get in the DLC's, which are only wearable by Humans)

- The Graphical Aspects of the game (The graphics aren't ♥♥♥♥♥♥ AT ALL!)

- The Customization system (Character style choosing, including: Voice of a character, facial expression, etc.)

- The Enchantments and Shop system (Self explanatory)

What I dislike about the game:

- Glitches
(The only problem I did notice occuring sometimes..But very Rare, trust me, this WILL NOT ruin your gameplay!)

I would definitely purchase the game because its OVERALL amazing.
~Quiirex

reviewText: My Playthrough          Youtube Playlist                 The Review        Dragon Age: Origins as it stands is one of my all time favorite RPGs. This game succeeds at so many points. The game has a great story, setting, gameplay, characters, and mod support. I love the setting of thedas as it has so much potential for stories that can span multiple games. The great characters are what really help this game stands out from other similar RPGs. Every character is memorable, from the companions to the NPCs. Every companion is a 3 dimensional characters. And if you personally dislike a companion you will never find yourself outright hating them. The gameplay is very much like that of Star Wars: Knights of the Old Republic which is also a very good game. But the by far best aspect of this game is the story. You can choose from multiple origins, races, and classes. And these choices and the choices made during the main quest makes each playthrough different. This is one of the few games that I played through more then 20 times. The downloadable content add much more hours of gameplay plus with the mod support this game gets even more hours of replay value. This is by far one of the best RPGs I played and I can't recommend it enough.

reviewText:
Electronic Arts Dragon Age: Origins RPG is for its time a breakthrough for a RPG game.

The Good

1)  Play one of three different races, each having a different story line. This is presented at the start of your story.
2)  Play one of three classes, Warrior, Rouge, or Mage.  At a higher level the class you choose can be improved to have skills like for example (Holy Smite) for the Warrior class.
3)  What you choose to say for your Gray Warden will effect your RPC group and the story outcome.
4)  Many quests during the Main story and side quests. To gain coin, favor from RPC's and loot.
5)  Have a relationship either male, female, or both! Naughty Naughty!
6)  Mixing your group. You can mix and match as much as you want between RPC in your party.

The not so Good

1) Plot never changes so if you complete the Story at Normal level and play again at Hard level (Ho Hum) you already know what to do.  Of course it may take a long period of time to defeat the Archdeamon's army.
2)  What? my (Gray Warden) is a mute? Kinda,  It would have been better to have him/her speak the sentence you have choosen.  When you choose a action for the (Gray Warden) it is acted out during the game.
3) Weapons and Armor stay fresh and new, it would have been interesting to have items get worn or become damaged.

The game is addictive if you a first time player or return to it after a while.  What is nice with the Ultimate edition is that after you play the main story you can transfer your (Gray Warden) to one of the other stories to start another adventure.

reviewText:
Dragon Age: Origins is my favorite game of all times, and I am absolutely loving every bit of it. I must have finished it 5 times by now, and I still find myself drawn to it every year or so. It takes me about 120 hours to fully complete the Ultimate Edition. The Ultimate Edition of Dragon Age: Origins is the complete bundle consisting of Dragon Age: Origins, its expansions and its DLCs in a single release.


Which means that there is a huge world to explore: vast cities, villages, abandoned dwarven thaigs, large forests, underground caverns, ancient ruins, swamps, mountains, towers and citadels, palaces and estates, stores and taverns, caves and highways. Oh, I could go on for hours about all the places you could visit throughout your playthroughs. It's up to you, my dear reader, to take heart and embark on a journey like none you have ever had. And thanks to the insane amount content, detail, customization, and features - every playthrough will grant you a new experience.

There are six origins - background stories for player characters — that are playable in Dragon Age: Origins and a seventh in Dragon Age: Origins - Awakening. These playable backstories will allow the Warden to put themselves in a specific role within the social structure of Ferelden and will help explain motivations for the Warden joining the Grey Wardens. There are three main Races you can choose from: Human, Dwarf and Elf. After choosing your Origins and Race, you will get to choose your Class and Specialization. There are three classes – warrior, rogue and mage – in Dragon Age: Origins, each with four specializations. Six additional specializations were added in the expansion Dragon Age: Origins - Awakening. To be honest, all my 5 complete playthroughs were as a Human Mage. Gifted with a power considered dangerous by most, mages were always my favorite.

reviewText: This game is the best example for how RPG's should be: epic advenure, interesting companions, customizable combat and the making of a character that feels like it's your own. What it makes it unique is the fact that you can choose an origin story for a specific race(human, elf or dwarf) which makes a real difference throughout the game. Each character has it's own tale, so each romance is something new. You have a whole nation to explore and unite under your command. As  a Grey Warden, you'll  put kings on their thrones, solve mystic mysteries, fight in glorious(and large in scale) battles. In this edition, you'll also enjoy a what-if scenario(the bad guys win), an origin story(of a naughty bard), a big expansion pack that gives your character a worthy story, a nightmareish adventure with big rewards and an epilogue with the companion who you do not fully understand in the main story. The game also has a strong modding comunity(it's own nexus site). I played a lot of it on the PS3 and I intend to do hundreds of hours with it on steam, because every playthrough is a new experience(so many varieties, I find myself not doing things the same way). This game will always be a 9.5

reviewText:
One of the best games I've ever played.  I usually can't play through a story based RPG game more than once, but I played this one 4 times all the way through and a bunch more just for origin stories.

Origins means there are many different introductory storylines depending on the race/class you pick (6 in total I believe) that all have different starting stories which integrate into the main story.  It's so engrossing that characters you meet later on while playing an Elf are characters that belong to other race/class' origin stories and vice versa.  There are so many fine details to the story this way, and you have a chance to manipulate everything based on your actions and outcomes of choices.

On top of the grand story comes gameplay.  It's a classic RPG style (like Baldur's Gate), but with modern enhancements and features so that it doesn't feel ancient or clunky.  The combat is pausable and strategic, not arcade-like.

reviewText:
Still my favorite Dragon Age game of all time, even over Inquisition. (And favorite game of all time probably).
-My Warden flirted with absolutely everyone, even some random village girl who kissed his cheek
-Was a sarcastic snot toward the king without consequence
-Insulted an old lady whenever he had the chance
-Fought Gaxkang and got stuck in the wall, the ceiling AND the floor.
-Couldn't even bomb self to get killed, forced to return to a different save or live in a wall/ceiling/floor forever.
-Alistair somehow lost his face and had it morph back into his empty templar armored shell of a body during a cutscene
-Warden somehow fell through the floor in Orzammar, died and then came back.
-Warden also died during Shale's quest by falling into a water pool that should have been impossible to reach, and somehow resurrected himself to start fighting the last boss of the quest alone.
-Made Alistair extremely uncomfortable with lamppost licking conversations
-Warden consistently outlived Alistair as the tankiest rogue that has probably ever existed
-Consistently made forward comments toward every camp member possible with zero regrets
-Made terrible life choices that effected the entire country
-Gave zero ♥♥♥♥s doing so
-Repeatedly trolled Justice with the silvertongue perk
-Enabled Anders' cat addiction
-Sadly glitches were fixed after the character completed the game but honestly the glitches made my score a solid 10/10 for amusement factor alone. Have never had another character I enjoyed half as much. ** (this character was made when the game first came out)

Highly recommended. Great characters, diverse maps, and interesting storylines.

reviewText:
Witches Don't Wear Bras - An Official Waffle King Review
~Find more here.[www.nonm.co.uk]

Swords and junk are pretty cool. When I was little I liked to pretend that sticks were swords and swing them at the kids on the bus stop that I didn't like. They always said to watch out or I'd poke their eyes out. But I showed them. Oh, I showed them. Little did I know, that was little baby Waffle King's first little foray into the world of roleplaying games. I could be whatever I wanted, and I could wield powerful weapons beyond your imagination. Like those perfect sticks that make whistling noises when you swing them.


As I grew older, of course RPG games would be a genre I got pulled back to time and time again. But in this day and age, true roleplaying games have become harder to come by. The big guys upstairs, the game publishers that control what we play, they don't want those. Because you know what, those games are hard. They're really hard. Making choices is hard. Consequences are hard. It's so much easier if you can just mash buttons and make things happen. And if you want to learn every skill? You can do that. It's okay.


Hardcore RPG's aren't a genre that's explored often by big publishers. They're a niche type of game. One of the biggest developers of RPG's of that nature, Bioware, is still around. But sadly, there's a lot of corporate fingers in their ♥♥♥.


They've made some of the greatest RPG classics. And some other games. Those were alright. Even after being acquired by EA, they still put out a number of quality games. Before, you know. It happened. RIP.


Dragon Tales Origins was one of the first games to come out under the new EA and Bioware partnership, launching on Xbox 360, Playstation 3, and PC; it's a spiritual successor to Neverwinter Nights and the acclaimed Baldur's Gate games.


Ever watch that one movie Lord of the Rings? Kinda like that, only you get to bang a witch.


She doesn't really wear clothes or anything. She has some shower curtains or something over her shoulder.


Dragon Tales is a pretty good game. A hardcore tactical strategy RPG, with an emphasis on the roleplaying aspect. You become the guy with the sword that does the things. You are him or her. You get to bang that witch and save the world. It's all you, buddy.


A grand tale of zombies and witch ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥, Dragon Tales Origins is extremely heavy with lore. They really went all out trying to build this fantasy world. They got the elves, the dwarves, and all that good stuff. Completely original lore, totally not just Lord of the Rings with some things switched around. In fact, they were so proud of their work they even went and named it Origins. They were planning ahead. They already knew it was gonna be big. They were gonna make a series out of it from the very beginning. And ♥♥♥♥, they really wrote a ♥♥♥♥ing book. It's a book, a book with some RPG elements mixed in. I didn't pay attention in History class, the ♥♥♥♥ you think I'm gonna memorize the lore of Dragon Tales for?


It's written well at least, and the characters are a joy to be around. They're colorful and multi-dimensional, and you can sex them all up. Not all at once, they get mad at you for trying to do that. Which is definitely holding me back from giving the game a perfect score. You can even do gay things in Origins, one of the defining features that made it so popular with the Tumblr crowd. You can gay things up, and that is clearly what gay people look for most in their games. They're mostly awkward teenage girls actually, they love gay sex more than actual gay people. But you know, this is exactly what they look for in a game and they're free to like what they like.


Writing would be what I'd say is Dragon Tales' best trait. It's visually a little dated, with a pretty good soundtrack. But the writing, ooh wee, that's some good swords and magic ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t. An RPG like Origins thrives on writing, though. It's all about pulling you in, letting you live the role of a dude with a sword in a medieval setting.


The only problem with this setup is that the game mechanics aren't quite welcoming to the whole swords thing. In fact, I really wouldn't recommend using swords at all. Just don't, for your own good.


You get to build your own character and assign them one of several backstories, races, and classes. It encourages you to make many different characters, to see the story from different angles and to make different choices to see the outcome should you have made one choice instead of the other. But what the game fails to encourage is using any class other than mage. Really, the mage is the best thing to play and is the only thing I'd recommend.


A knight or warrior's job is to walk into monsters and take up space while mages attack and heal. Rogues are fun also, allowing you free rein over the battlefield to just kinda walk around, stab guys in the back, and all that good stuff. But mages get the most cool things to use. Exploding lightning, blizzards, and summoning giant spiders and ♥♥♥♥. It's the definitive way to play this game by a long shot. Not to mention how poorly balanced they are. If you're fighting enemies and there's an enemy mage, you gun for that guy first because he can crush your entire party in no time. And it's the exact same vice versa. So you're gonna want to take good care of your mage.


You get to order your party members around as well, so if you do choose to make your main character something other than the best class in the game you can always just play as ♥♥♥♥♥ witch. Who is the best character in the game.


Ordering around your allies isn't exactly optional however. They don't really have much in terms of AI. Their default tactics are to headbutt monsters while singing the U.S. National Anthem, The Star-Spangled Banner. Classic song, great song. But it helps out much more if you can command them to fight strategically. You have to pretty much program them through a bunch of clunky menus, which is my favorite thing in a game. You know me, I like my menus how I like that ♥♥♥. Hard to handle and all over the place. If it takes me less than ten minutes to get from Point A to Point B, it just isn't clunky enough. I want to spend hours trying to work that ♥♥♥. Menus and asses like that are a true work of perfection and are the clear indicator of brilliant game design. Swapping between characters on the fly works well if you're gonna fight that way also, but also can be very intensive during major fights.


I'd still consider it one of my favorite RPG's, even if it has numerous little flaws and hasn't aged well in some regards. I've enjoyed multiple playthroughs, and it is still fun the second and third time. There's definitely a clear right way to play it, which is as a mage and on PC. Keyboard shortcuts, hotkeys, and the superior camera controls and options really make it the definitive way to play. But it's still decently enjoyable however you should tackle it. PC users have mods though also, so you can see uncensored ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥ and stuff. That's why people mod stuff in the first place.


It's a wordy game, full of reading and numbers and nerd things. But it's immersive and fun, and a testament to Bioware's secret formula to making some of the best RPG's. Well it's not exactly a secret, you just need to be able to sex people, commit genocide, and unite the many tribes to vanquish a great evil that you told everyone was coming and no one listened.


Dragon Tales always reminds me of raisins though. When I first played it, I was just kind of marathon-playing it and needed a snack. But there was nothing at all to eat in my house. Nothing but raisins. And it was a giant industrial-size can of raisins too. It had like 100 servings or something. So I just ate raisins while I played. That's all I had. I've learned from my mistakes, and I keep other things stocked up now. You just gotta live and learn, man. Just live and learn.

reviewText: This game is defintly one of the best games i've ever played and one of my favourites (if not my favourite). The gameplay is great, second to none, the storyline coundn't be anybetter BioWare really knows how to pull it off as shown in also in their Mass Effect Series. The storyline does well to get you attached to the game by making the descions that you make effect how the story pans out for you for the rest of the game and its expansions (classic BioWare tho i must note). The chat dialouges and cutscenes are always dramatic and never cease to bore you and always seem to add to the drama and hype of the already superb Storyline, the quests are never boring and their are endless side quests to do besides the storyline, this game will last you weeks on end.The characters in this game are represented very well, with so many different personallities in the game you are never left short from any chat dialogue. As for things to do other than questes you can't fall short, Poison Making, Trap Making, Tactics, Enchanting, Gathering and much more, I'm sure you wouldn't run out of things to do. As far as i am concerned i have not come across any glitchs or problems though bearing in mind it is a game and i am sure i will encounter one soon enough. I would recomend this game to anyone that really likes RPG games that have a great storyline and good feel overall to the gameplay, this game is like all the good things from The Elder Scrolls Series and The Diablo Series put together it is just great and i cannot stop playing it, best $7.50 i've ever spent and I would be willing to pay the actual price of around $20-$30 for this game because it is worth every cent you pay for. Had this game not gone on sale i would've never bought it, hats off to Valve for putting this game on sale and getting this gem out of the rough. Everyone NEEDS to get this game, you'll regret not getting it.

reviewText:
Dragon Age Origins is a game of fierce strategy, engaging characters and amazing narrative.

You start the game off in one of the various origin stories. Almost all of these are well done, and serve to really lend an identity to your player character. After that you are thrust onto a tale of revenge which prompts you to gather all of the various powers in the land toward survival, or risk extinction.

What Dragon Age Origins does well is moral ambiguity and effective characterization. All of your party members have unique and interesting backstories, many of whom are entirely optional to recruit and you could just as easily murder them if you please. This also extends to the villains, who are all very complex and have some of the best dialogue in the game.

This is the Ultimate Edition which includes all of the paid DLC Bioware released, including the expansion pack Dragon Age Awakening. All of the little DLC like the preorder packs have already been released for free. Making this the definitive edition of the game, and a must play for anyone who likes RPGs. Bioware also released an SDK for the game, and hundreds of modifications have been released for it.

Take in Dragon Age Origins, few games like it are still made today.

reviewText:
This my friends is how a game is truly made. Its got a world and story that grips you by the ball's and sucks you in for the word go. Its got amazing supporting characters that are simply a joy to talk to and its got interesting set pieces and enemies to fight.

It doe's however have slightly clunky gameplay for those that are not used it its isemetric view, party combat style but is fun to play if you know what you are doing.

In short its a regular Bioware game.
10/10 would be willing to sacrifce my life for anyone of my party members and feel truly guilty for any bad choice's I make or those that die because of me, again

reviewText:
I finished this game last night live on stream. It took me about 3 weeks of playing for about 3/4 hours per night. It is a fantastic game with an incredibly amazing storyline and well thought out characters. The game is left open for replayability because of the way you can a) pick different characters/background b) the way you can delivery yourself to the AI in the game and c) the difficulties. I played the game on Normal throughout, however I could easily go back and play it on Easy for a more RPG style type of game or on a higher difficulty for a more stategic style type of game, which I will most likely do.
The music as well in the game is fantastic.

I would highly recommend this game for anyone who enjoys diving into a vast world with lots of story and characters where you can pick how you play! 10/10 from me!
