reviewText:
This franchise has become a byword for fantasy rpg. The first game in the series however, Dragon Age: Origins, has set the bar a bit too high and is regarded as a classic masterpiece by gamers and critics both.
If you enjoy rpg games you should definitely not miss out playing this great game.
It's highly replayable with many character classes, story changing choices and interesting companions with their own personalities, and a single playthrough can go up to a hundred hours or more.
voteText: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful 1 person found this review funny

reviewText:
Depressing as it is to know that this (and Mass Effect 2) were the last good Bioware games, Dragon Age Origins stands as one of my favorite games, considering that it is one of the few games that I can enjoy from start to finish.
Pros:
-The game contains a great amount of content. You can easily sink 60 hours into the base game
-The cast of characters following the protagonist are memorable and well written. In fact, they are about on par with the cast in Knights of the Old Republic
-The gameplay is well balanced and may often require you to use your brain, especially in higher difficulty settings
-The dialogue is well written, and your character's attributes may determine what you want him or her to say
-Each of the 6 different origin stories are very entertaining, and even offer a degree of replay value
-Your choices in the game actually have an affect on the outcome of the story and are far from black/white, as a cunning player may find a compromise if all the availible options are assessed
-The soundtrack fits the mood quite well, though (aside from a few tracks) there's none that really stand out to the point where I'd go out of my way to listen to it
Cons:
-There are difficulty spikes in certain areas of the game
-The tedious fade section
-The extremely akward romance scenes
-Magic can be quite over powered to the point where it takes only one mage to influence the outcome of the fight
-Although the Player Character can do some very horrible things, there isn't exactly an evil" ending
Verdict:
Dragon Age Origins is an extremely entertaining role playing game that offers a vast amount of content. If you are a fan of Bioware games
date: you'd be doing yourself a disservice by not playing this. If I had to rate the game
hoursPlayed: February 1

reviewText: Don't let the few hours played fool you - I have a full playthrough and then some on a non-steam version.\nThis is truly a great game - it offers several different stories and events, and what you do can really effect the later ongoings.\nA good and long story makes this one of the best RPGs the last 10 years. The story clocks in between 40 and 70 hours, depending on how many of the branching stories you wish to explore (and how long you take doing that). Add in epic monsters, multiple followers (all with their own personality), and mountains of loot, and you have a winning combination.

reviewText:
I just started playing this game again after I got a little bored with Skyrim and Eve Online.

Dragon Age: Origins is an amazing game.  It's graphics have withstood the test of time, and the story has a way of still feeling fresh: even though I am playing as an elf rogue, again, the number of choices that affect the outcome make it feel like a completely new experience.  The only real complaint I have is that the camera controls are a little dodgy at times, but this is a minor gripe and it has not deterred me.

Bottom line: if you're are currently on a budget and want to experience an amazing RPG with deep lore, strategic combat, and an amazing story, then you should buy this now.  If you are really on a budget, put it on your wishlist and buy it when it is on sale.

reviewText: Great fun! Dragon Age has you taking on the role of the newest Grey Warden, travelling the lands of Ferelden recruiting allies to fight against a new blight of Darkspawn - a blight not taken seriously by others in the kingdom.\n\nThis game is definitely the spiritual successor of the Baldur's Gate series, with a deep, complex storyline that twists and shapes according to your choices as the Warden. The excellent writing and voice acting keep the game feeling fresh; I thought the humourous exchanges between different party members were particularly fantastic. I've enjoyed Dragon Age immensely so far and would strongly recommend it to fans of roleplaying games, fantasy settings and those who love a compelling story.

reviewText:
This is the perfect game for anyone who likes tactical games as well as in-depth RPGs and especially for those who like romances and of course, especially for someone who like all three.

The battles allow you to pause and give all of your party members orders, such as telling them to move to a certain position on the field or to use a certain skill in battle. Among other things, you can also place traps and use poisons or other items to exploit certain weaknesses. At first, combat may be a little difficult with getting used to the controls and such but it then gets a little easier, to the point you can play without pausing but be warned - the difficulty does go up again soon afterwards, there are many battles you won't win without pausing and thinking about how your party should be reacting to the situation. * You can also set automated tactics for each party member, including your own character, for when you're not controlling them.

This is the type of game that actually gets you interested in the lore around it - I know I personally have issues getting into the lore in a lot of games, but it just kind of sucked me in. The world feels so complete that you'll want to learn everything you can. As far as RPG goes, you play a silent protagonist of your choice (several different options, such as a run away bride or a nobleman) and make decisions that will impact your entire game, as well as Dragon Age 2 if you choose to play that as well. There are three or four main endings but keep in mind they are all of a similar premise so do not expect something like one of the alternate Silent Hill endings with aliens.

The characters are extremely engaging and varied in personality. They even react uniquely to each other - some hating or liking others. You get to see these reactions either in the form of banter while traveling, as an aside when you're having a conversation with another character in public(wandering) or even with certain character combinations in scenes. It is also possible to somewhat shape their personalities to the extent of continuing to be who they are or becoming stronger" socially.

As far as romance goes

recommended: with only one of the opposite gender characters changing per your gender

reviewText: If I were ruler of the world I would make a playthrough of this game mandatory every five years. This is the greatest game ever crafted by humans(in my opinion). The characters have nuances and personality and you get attached and are saddened and one of the endings made me sob. Actually sob. Tears and everything. The lady I always end up macking on is my favorite character in any form of media. The next is the protagonist of this game, in spite of and actually due in part to the fact that the character has no voice, even though you are clearly talking. It's better for immersion. This game has that in spades. It's beautiful and atmospheric and deep and by god it's depressing. It's gritty, serious, dark, gory, sad, and depressing. This game almost constantly beats you over the head with horrid events that make you curl into the fetal position with the brutality. But this backing makes the touching and comical moments stick out more and makes it great. In summary, play it or suffer the consequences.

reviewText:
Revisiting one of my favourite RPG and I'm speechless again. Dragon Age : Origins has everything it needs to be a perfect game : mesmerizing music, amazing companions, interesting story, funny characters and quests, effective combat system, variety of spells and skills.

If you like Bioware games - Baldur's Gate - RPGs - you've got to try Dragon Age out !

Chose between a human, a dwarf or an elf ; a warrior, a thief or a mage and build your character as you wish : the game offers a lot of different choices that will change the story one way or another. Who are you gonna help ? Who are you gonna kill ? Who are you gonna let die ?

Dive into this unique adventure and discover a huge fantasy world in dire need of a hero (and his loyal and unique companions !).

reviewText:
Brilliant game. Excellent choice&consequence, extensive lore, solid RPG mechanics and combat, though held back a lot by over-reliance on the MMO healer-tank-DPS archetype, instead of sticking with the D&D mechanics that made Baldur's Gate great. But still, the combat is engaging and never too easy. A lot of content also - 54 hours in and I have only completed the main game; I still have to do all the DLCs as well as the expansion pack Awakening.

Dragon Age: Origins was probably one of the best RPGs in the few years before and after its release. It's a shame about the sequels because Bioware could have turned this franchise into something truly great. Origins looks, feels, and plays like a cRPG, and was developed primarily for PC, but its sequels had a console audience in mind and it shows. The squandered potential of Dragon Age is just one more thing EA has run into the ground.

reviewText:
This is easily one of my favorite games of all time. The plot is completely fascinating, the characters feel like real people, and your choices will have far-reaching consequences. Sometimes doing the right thing is not the best option, which is why this game can be absolutely visceral.

The graphics are a bit dated, but with some artful modding (and there are some fantastic mods out there) and a little imagination, this game is a true adventure.

The sheer size of this game is startling. Not in maps (of which there are plenty), but in depth. The characters all have fascinating backstories, but the world itself is what truly shines. The codexes in this are nearly an art form. This is a living, breathing world, where religion, politics, and simple humanity are the most beautiful and poignant characters, rather than the companions that walk with you.

reviewText: Dragon Age: Origins was the game that set the bar for me when it comes to fantasty RPGs. It is, without a doubt, one of my favorite games ever. The story is compelling, extremely dark and well-thought through. There wasn't a moment when I felt the game was bad, even if it has a few frustrating parts. It takes you on an incredible journey and let's you make very hard decisions along the way. Even though the combat can feel a little clunky at times, it doesn't hurt the rest of the game. You have intriguing companions and interesting ways to expand your friendships with them. It has great replay value if you are interested to see how the game's world will treat you as a different race, class and with different choices. I recommend this game 110%.

reviewText:
This is one of the last BIoWare games that *felt* like a BioWare game after their acquisition by Electronic Arts. It is a RTwP RPG with a pretty average main plot, but what makes it shine is the excellent writing and personalities of the companions you pick up on your adventure to stop the big-bad. If you play this game the right way, you will grow attached to the characters after spending 20-40 hours killing monsters with them, learning about their past, goals and desires along the way. Each character is distinct from one another, and fleshed out to make you really care about their ultimate fate. That doesn't stop you from being a complete scum bag to them, which yeilds its own rewards in the form of comedy (At least for me)

The combat system is accessible, but not simplistic enough that you can go into each battle and not use tactics, (Not on higher difficulty settings at least).  Some battles require a great deal of thinking in order to devise the perfect strategy to take down a large group of enemies, or a tough boss. There are a large number of skills and talents to learn as you level up, as well as 3 different classes to choose from (Rogue, Mage, Warrior) which each have a few of their own sub-classes called specializations which also hold different abilities to learn, which makes the game extremely replayable right off the bat, even if there weren't multiple ending (Which there are). But there are also different Origin stories, as the title suggests. Dwarven Noble, Dwarven Commoner, Dalish Elf, City Elf, Human Noble and Circle Mage, which adds even more replayability since each origin story and race choice changes certain dialogues, the opening act and even certain missions down the road.

Those who can't get enough swag will be delighted to know that there are plenty of epic armor, weapons and other loots to be found here to slaughter things with, which makes it a pleasure to play if you can't get enough of the cosmetic side of RPGs. The only thing I have a problem with is that the mage class has a very limited selection of rather boring robes to sport, and that is disappointing. There are also plenty of sidequests to complete over the course of your adventure, which range from dull fetch quests to epic dragon slaying.

So in conclusion, the game is quite good. The characters are memorable, the combat is fun and challenging, plenty of armor and weapons to choose from, multiple endings and hours of content to play. It is well worth the money, in my opinion.

That is all.

reviewText:
I overall enjoyed this game and consider it Bioware's swan song.

The origin story chosen by the player impacts not only your dialogue options, but also the level of classism and fantastical racism encountered.

The female Dalish elf has few rights, lives in poverty(walled off segregated part of the city), and gets taken to be a mistress for the local noble. She has little social mobility and only gets out of her scenario from being enlisted by the Gray Wardens. There is no social justice, only results matter from her actions afterward. This provided for me a sense of agency in my actions versus being dropped into say roleplaying as Geralt of Rivia in the Witcher series.

The Noble female noble’s story is also one of revenge. Yet she can still do more. She can by my count simultaneously be: Queen consort of Fereldan, Teyrna of Gwaren, the second in line heir to Highever, Commander of the Grey in Fereldan, and Arlessa of Amaranthine. That is like... Michelle Obama if she was also Governor of Florida, heir of California, and Mayor of New York City and Marshal General of all the armed forces.

There are many origins but only one Duncan to help that origin character. The others origin characters are dead if they do not get enlisted. The player can encounter the Dwarf commoner’s corpse in a part of the plot. With no Duncan to enlist him, he refuses to eat and thus dies in prison.

The format of the vanilla campaign follows the usual Bioware formula. The main character must travel to four locations, solve the local issues and convince that faction to help in the final battle. You are hunted by the darkspawn and will encounter a vision/dream sequence with the big bad. As you travel you will encounter the ruins of an ancient civilization (lost dwarven thaigs/Prothiens/Underdark) lost over time yet full of artifact tier items and lore.

The gameplay is similar to Baldur’s gate but does not rely on the daily spell count limit of D&D gameplay. Mages are far stronger than many other classes for regular enemies. With some exceptions such as the Gaxkang lich battle.

This game reminded me of Baldur’s Gate a lot. If the Warden badly handles decisions, party members will leave the party and even challenge you for leadership. The backgrounds of the characters should be considered in your political dealings. During the Landsmeet, if you arranged for Anora and Alistair to marry it can backfire if you let Loghain live and join the order to redeem himself. To conscript Loghain into the Wardens will make Alistair furious. To Alistair, joining the Grey Wardens is a sacred duty and honor, it is not a death sentence. By contrast, if you let Alistair execute Logain, Anora will break down the political alliance as she cannot marry the killer of her father.

What I found charming in this game was the fact that character interactions and growth seems to happen naturally. Alistair’s reception to mages was something I felt was handled very well. His early training was that of a Templar, a role sworn to strike down mages if they are taken over by demons of the Fade. Yet Alistair is scared of Morrigan and neutral to Wynne. At first glance you may think he hates all mages. But the reason he distrusts Morrigan so much is not just because she is a mage. Rather the issue is that Morrigan is a maleficar, someone outside of the rules of the Chantry. She practices unknown magic (shapeshifting, is neutral to blood magic rituals, etc) that he has been taught all of his life is evil and wrong. He is actually terrified of her.

reviewText: Dragon Age: Origins offers one of the best single-player rpg experiences on th PC. It has a rich and detailed lore surrounding the game world that sets up the stage for your adventures in the game. The main story is also very intriguing and is full of twists and turns that will keep you entertained for the whole ride. It also offers many side-quests that flesh out the world with many unique stories, and every conversation you have reveals more information about the world of Dragon Age. If you love a good fantasy world, than Dragon Age doesn’t fail to disappoint.\n\nThe story is the traditional Bioware set-up, with a bit of a twist. When you create your character, you get to pick a race, an origin and a gender. Depending on your choices, the characters in the world will treat you differently. More importantly, you play a short 30-60 minute intro story that is unique to your origin. Then there is a 30-60 minute general intro sequence that you play, before the world opens up. You have to travel to multiple different locations, in any order you choose, in order to get different factions to pledge their loyalty to you for a battle against the game’s main enemy, the Darkspawn. Each area you go to have its own problems that you must sort out before they will pledge allegiance to you. Like everything you do in Dragon Age, solving these problems tells you more about the society and world of Dragon Age. The story continues on and ends in a grand finale. The main is very interesting.

reviewText:
I LOVE BioWare RPGs, and I ♥♥♥♥ing -LOVE- Dragon Age: Origins!

I first played it on Xbox 360, and then replayed it, and replayed it, seriously about fifteen times (plus every 'origin' story), not to mention all the time spent to unlock certain achievements.

The game has a myriad of complex, flawed and ultimately loveable (or loathable) characters, with a consequence (or reward) for your every action. The world is vast, steeped in history and lore, and though the game is set only in the one country, Fereldan, you still get a sense of the larger scheme.

The gameplay... It took me a little while to learn the controls on the 360, but I'm finding this time around playing on PC the controls are a little more intuitive. Everything else seems to be the same. Fully customisable tactics for your party members, interchangeable weapons, armour and skills, class specialisations, crafting, healing, set and skill bonuses, auto attack and quick slot skills, and the ability to pause the game in order to issue commands.

When I saw the Ultimate Edition on Steam, all bundled together and so damn cheap I knew there was no question, I had to get it!

Still the same epic game I fell in love with all those years ago <3

reviewText:
My goodness what an epic game!

I wont go into details story wise or combat as im sure by now you  have an idea. Put another 20 hours on this and you will get my gameplay time. I started playing the standard edition then realized what an awesome game it is and bought the ultimate edition full price well worth it!

This is up there with some of my favourite ever games! Truly epic! The story was so immersive. There was never a time I wanted to get to the end. Infact I didn't want it to end and im not sure I have ever felt like that about a game. The biggest compliment I can give this is its as good as some of my favourite books.

I thought the characters were a bit quirky at first but boy did they grow on you. They ended up feeling like friends, you get to know them and like them even the more difficult ones lol (probably need to get out more) but its truly a testament to the writing and voice acting superb! I got choked up at the end.

It was a tough game also it gave me a fight the whole way through but you truly feel like you have lived it at the end. Took me a little while to get my game style together and choose characters that worked well, once I had I was rolling.

Absolutely loved it! Sad it has ended. Two big thumbs up and a big toe.

Edit Review 1.25.2015 Played dlc.

Well well to my joy and astonishment I hadn't played through all the dlc. I thought that all the dlc was part of the game and then I looked into a section called other campaigns I think and there was all this content I hadn't realized was there Oh Joy!

If you loved the game as much as me then this was just such a treat. There was a small standalone story nothing to do with our story but in the world which was fun. There was even a story from the point of the Darkspawn. Awakenings is really were the money was spent a proper campaign and an excellent addition to the story. It really is your story there was some major plot changing decision that really changed the narrative and ended my story interestingly. Im not sure I made the right decision but thats life, thats Rpg. Then a tale of Morrigan which left me asking more questions than answering and I felt sad for my virtual friend.

What a trip. Nearly a !00 hours in total for £20.00. I would say thats bang for buck. Loved it!

reviewText:
Dragon Age Origins: Ultimate Edition

Positives:

+ This game is a tactical based RPG, requiring frequent pauses in combat to issue party orders. Each class has unique strengths and weaknesses, mages, rogues and warriors alike all contribute something special to the battles. The game itself is very challenging but satisfying and fun at the same time.
+ Rogues can learn the art of dual wielding and typically fit in as party DPSER, while Mages have access to a plethora of spells, from aoe and single target disables, to healing, revivals, nuke damage and more. Warriors can inflict savage damage with two handed weapons or tank enemies with a shield and armour.

+ The dialogue and story in Dragons Age Origins: Ultimate Edition is amazing. Bioware are well known for their fantastic storytelling and this game is no exception. There are memorable characters who you can build friendships with and complete quests for. Romance is also an option. The main plot is well thought-out and maintains your interest.
+There's a large number of side quests to complete, around 120 hours of content in total with the expansions. Plenty of moral decision making which impacts on the story progression too.
+ Lots of random event encounters, with forests, temples and ancient ruins to explore, along with several cities.


Mixed:

~ For 2009 the graphics are not the best, but by no means are they terrible. This is definitely no reason to avoid the game.


Negatives:

- Some redundant skills, like trap making or survival, that don't seem to serve any useful purpose.

Overall Score 9/10

Dragons Age Origins: Ultimate Edition is a really solid game in pretty much every respect. Well worth purchasing on sale for $10 or less. In fact, many digital distributors are offering this price daily, so don't miss out.

reviewText:
Dragon Age is a fantastic RPG that lasted longer than I thought it would. I finished it in 40 hours, but it could easily take you 20 hours longer to complete everything.

The characters have depth, the story is pretty good, the graphics also still look very good and the gameplay is tight for a 3D RPG. It can be a bit unbalanced at times though, so I had to change the difficulty from time to time in order to advance. It's disappointing but, it never really frustrates.
The isometric view is actually very helpful and, in my opinion, works better than the default camera view. I do admit that the default view is the more cinematic one, but for the later battles isometric view is recommended, required even.

Dragon Age is a title that I immensely enjoyed. It's one of the better RPGs of the last decade so if RPG is your thing you should definitely play this.

(Play the second one as well. Despite the repetitiveness of the environments it's also well worth a playthrough and it's not as bad as people say it is).

[Rating: 92/100]

reviewText:
Dragon Age, when it arrived, was a game that I had been waiting on for a very long time. Having been criminally denied more KotOR (which is what I truly wanted), this was as close as I was going to get to that same feeling; Squad-based tactical RPG with a heavy emphasis on character interaction, development and choice... Just describing it makes me want to fire it up again.

The setting and tone is similar to Game of Thrones, but before the show even existed; A dark fantasy that delves into intrigue, mystery, deception and tragedy. Not to mention a heavy dose of epic adventure. Of course the game doesn't always take itself so seriously, taking cues from its predecessor by implementing some charming, quirky characters and an overall sense of hope in the darkness. The consistenly excellent writing, VO and art design all come together in a way that helps you get lost in the universe they created.

The story, and how it unfolds, is really quite good. As the name suggests, your origin is important, and what you choose to be at the beginning will have a noticeable impact on your path. However, everyone ultimately finds their way into the arms of the Grey Wardens, a jedi-esque order of warriors devoted to stopping a horde of darkspawn from spreading throughout the land. They recruit you, train you, and before you know it, throw you into the fire. What happens in the next 40-60 hours is for you to discover. That number will of course grow considerably if you get all of the DLC.

Origins is unique for a modern Western game, in the sense that it is actually fairly challenging. The enemies, especially a few hours into the game, are tough and it only gets harder. Even on normal difficulty you will likely get your ♥♥♥ kicked a few times, soon to realize that a strategic approach is the best way to succeed. The combat is complex but it makes sense, taking the fundementals of KotOR and making it even deeper.

Of course now having said all of that, it looks like I'm going to be playing it soon... You should do the same.

reviewText:
The Dragon Age series(yes, that includes DA2) is my favorite RPG game series of all time.

I highly recommend this game if you enjoyed Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Night or the Mass effect series.

Story is well-written and the characters are the reason that I keep replaying this game. The lore of this game is huge and always interesting to read.

The music is beautiful and Aubrey Ashburn has a beautiful voice. The Voice acting is top-notch as well.

The combat is tactic-based with some micromanaging but that depends on the difficulty you are playing. You don't have to use tactics, but it will make the gameplay a breeze to play. If you don't like the speed of the combat, there is mod to speed it up.

There is also a website full of Dragon Age mods. I highly recommend playing the game vanilla mode, however.

The graphics are okay. But don't let it color your choice of purchasing this amazing game.

Anyways, I highly recommend buying this game and giving it a chance.

reviewText:
One of the best RPG out there, with hours upon hours of content, especially if you get the Ultimate Edition which brings all the game's DLC in the bundle, adding even more hours of gameplay and some interesting campaigns that differ from the main one, showing us more about certain characters, even allowing us to taste being part of the evil faction.

I will add here some points that go for the game and some that go against it.

Pros:
+It is a long game with a lot of content, a rare thing to find these days.
+It's side quests are where the game really shines, with a lot of ways to entertain the player in many different ways.
+Your choices change things in the world around you.
+It's background story is astoundingly well developed (As we have come to expect from bioware since games like KOTOR)
+The PC version has a more in depth tactical mechanic than its console counterpart, you can pause the game at any time to    give orders to your followers or to plan how to tackle certain enemies.
+Various origins to choose from that affect dialogues troughout the game. (Hence the game's title)
+Many build options and various specs branching from three base classes: Warrior, Mage and Rogue.

Cons:
-If you are someone that values graphics over other things keep in mind that this game came out in 2009, so it is bound to be graphicaly outdated (The graphics aren't bad tough).
-The main storyline is kind of typical and straightforward, and depending on your choices it might end in a way that leaves you with a bitter taste.
-The relationship system with your followers is not that well done, you might find that the character you are trying to romance in their highes approval level and still don't show any interest in taking your friendship further.
-It has mods, but the game's modding mechanics are kind of tough to get acustomed with, especially if you are new to modding games.

All in all it is a very good game and while it isn't perfect, since it is a mess to activate the dlc for some people, for example, it is a game that I do sincerely recommend.

10/10 -would play again-

reviewText:
A brilliant tactical RPG with a refreshing story(for once the main characters actually feel vulnerable) and a compellingly challenging gameplay, that will often force you to either rethink your approach on combat and tactically distribute your damage, or die at the hands of high level random encounters.

This game has every thing. From interesting characters to brilliant easter eggs. A must have for every RPG fan out there.

reviewText:
I was never really a fan of RPGs, so I was obviously having doubts about this one, but the story seemed interesting and a friend of mine really inspired me to play. I've made simultaneously the best and the worst decision in my life. Best because this game is excellent. It's magical (haha), the story drags you in if you have even a bit of compassion and the characters can really easily charm you and in no time you'll find yourself in love with one or all of them.
The reason I'm saying this was the worst decision in my life because the game ended.
I never want to let go of my first warden and the fights and the characters and the places... Even with the DLCs I just want to keep playing this. And the replay value on this game is absolutely amazing, I've played as a female human warrior on the first try and I knew it immediately that I want to try the other classes/races.
Just get this game if you want hours of exploring, humor and probably the most complex and interesting story ever.

reviewText: So I know that Steam says I've played only 91.3hrs, but I've played offline as well, and it's a total of about 125+ hours. I ADORE this game. It is absolutely worth it to buy the Ultimate Edition-however, I bought it on sale for $7.40 (midweek madness is GODSEND). The extra content is very useful (there's items, gifts and and even 2 map locations, as well as an additional party member) and the additional campaigns are very fun.\nThe story is very well developed, as are the characters. They're very vivid. The graphics are also fabulous. What I love the most about the story is how OPTIONAL it is; you can skip cutscenes by pressing escape, as well as dialogue. Much of the story comes from talking to NPC's as well as your party members, so if you are not a fan of story and are just there for the gameplay, you can easily skip it and go about your business.\nThe gameplay itself can be tricky for those not familiar with the tactics system. reviewText: This game is a masterpiece when it comes to videogames. It pairs challenging tactical battles with excellent plot and an interesting setting. The graphics are good for such a large open game during the time it was made and even if they aren't as amazing as current days, it does not subtract from it. What I found to be the best part about this game was that each battle I had to fight differently. Each one had the possibility of defeat, and their were rarely any easy battles that I didn't have to think while fighting. Also, story wise, the greatest part in my opinion were the characters. I did not dislike a single one of them, and they each one of them I related and cared about. Overall this game is one of the greatest RPG games I have ever played, and if you enjoy RPGs and haven't picked this up, do so now.

reviewText:
The Dragon Age series(yes, that includes DA2) is my favorite RPG game series of all time.

I highly recommend this game if you enjoyed Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Night or the Mass effect series.

Story is well-written and the characters are the reason that I keep replaying this game. The lore of this game is huge and always interesting to read.

The music is beautiful and Aubrey Ashburn has a beautiful voice. The Voice acting is top-notch as well.

The combat is tactic-based with some micromanaging but that depends on the difficulty you are playing. You don't have to use tactics, but it will make the gameplay a breeze to play. If you don't like the speed of the combat, there is mod to speed it up.

There is also a website full of Dragon Age mods. I highly recommend playing the game vanilla mode, however.

The graphics are okay. But don't let it color your choice of purchasing this amazing game.

Anyways, I highly recommend buying this game and giving it a chance.

reviewText: The game is great, but it suffers from many issues that cause great annoyance. It's not a gigantic roadblock, and there haven't been any game breaking moments. It doesn't prevent me from recommending the game, as it is superb, but if you are low on patience with games, you might want to leave this one aside, as it has bugs that have no excuse not to be fixed.

reviewText:
Dragon Age, the classic game brought to you by the makers of Mass Effect, KOTOR and Jade Empire. Certainly better than its half arsed sequal after EA ♥♥♥♥ed Bioware into a shell of its former self.

You are the grey warden and you'll be going on a quest to save the entire realm from darkness... yeah it's pretty much the typical good must triumph over good story, nothing really original but still interesting nonetheless. You'll battle creatures like the undead, dark monsters, and surprisingly a few dragons.
This is Biowares classical style of game, where the main character is a mute and there's a lot of detail to the world you inhabbit. I do prefer Dragon Age 2's voice acting and some of the characters, however in this game when you make a character from the start you have the freedom to make a human, elf or a dwarf and a choice of different backgrounds to start the story from. Whether you want to be a human noble or an Elf ranger, as well as the choice of class for your character, of which it is limited to 3: Warrior, Rogue and Mage. It would have been better if there were more of a variety of classes like the Elder Scrolls, or even their own game Mass Effect which has sci-fi rpg classes of about 6.

Dragon Age: Origins is a must have if you are an RPG nut and you like fantasy worlds inhabbited by Elves and Dwarves.

reviewText: Dragon Age: Origins will withstand the test of time. I don't want to go into a long review, but I will say a few short things. First, the combat is generally fun. It has its downfall's, but the tactical camera, numerous amounts of perks, and ability to switch characters always breathes life into combat. The graphics actually aren't terrible considering how old the game is. If that sort of thing really matters, go to Nexus Mods and install whatever you see fit. DA:O's story is fantastic. At first, I had to push my self to keep playing, but once I got to the open world the hours just flew by. There is a considerable amount of lore that I recommend you learn (it makes the whole experience more enjoyable), but it is not required. The DLC is a blast, no problems there. If you're interested in Dragon Age: Inquisition, I STRONGLY recommend you play Dragon Age: Origins. Playing Dragon Age: II would be handy, but I wouldn't consider it essential. If anyone has any questions, please send me a message. I love this game, and I would love to answer your questions.

reviewText:
One of the first PC games I've ever found myself playing through to the end, and want to do so again staight after. Dragon Age easily trumps any other single-player fantasy RPG, even the Elder Scrolls. The storyline is what makes this game one of the best games ever. It's dark, exciting, fun and immersive, and will leave you begging for more.

A shame about the sequel. Hopefully Bioware will learn from Dragon Age II and make Dragon Age III: Inqusition a lot better.

9/10

Bottom_Line: Great game with a great company.  It is easy to understand and is really fun. 10/10 CCC Media MEDIA TO THE MAX!!!

reviewText:
It took me, admittedly, way too long to think of a good review for this game. I owned it on console before I managed to get it for PC, so I've had a fairly long experience with this game.

This was the first BioWare game I had ever played, and while it took me a while to get really into it (I didn't own it at first so I didn't have much time for immersion), it's one of my favorite games. You get to play as 16 different combinations of class, race, and gender, each personalizing your intro sequence and every interaction you get to be apart of in the game. Not to mention you get to make your Hero look however you wish to.

It may seem like a run of the mill 'save the world, kill some things' game, but it's a lot deeper than that. You're brought into a world where every choice you make has an affect on another aspect.

All in all, I love this game to bits, and while after playing the other games in the series it may get pretty tedious to play through Origins again, it's always nice to return to the roots of the franchise and see how far the series has come.

10/10

reviewText: This game is just GREAT! What to say, it's like the old-time RPG where the combat is simple yet strategic and the story is deep with lots of detail. I've played this and awakening on the Xbox and I enjoyed it all. When I saw the Ultimate Edition for sale on Steam, I wasn't thinking of how long it was going to take to finish the game. No, I was thinking of the emersion that it previously brought to me and how I wanted to visit that. Most games you complete once and cannot do again since the emotion is ruined, but Dragon Age is something that I'm able to pick up and enjoy. I actually enjoy the dialogue and quests more so than the combat. The voice acting, the expressions, the movement, the atmosphere, everything just works.\n\nThe PC version is much cleaner than the console versions and adds some new features which makes it more the reason to pick up. I got it for $7.50! That's a steal of a deal!

reviewText:
I've played this game all the way through in every possible way on the xbox 360, at least 500 hours i reckon, i never put it down. this and mass effect 2 are my most favorite games of ALL time, oh and Timesplitters 3, but yeh this is an amazing Role playing Game. you make a character and feel so connected to every conversation, they have a responce for every kind of person. as an example there is some wounded guy near the start of the story who needs your help and you can just say your too busy, and when the people with you argue that point you can just say hes already dead... see... and slit his throat lol.
may not seem like much but its little things like that that make this game what it is. my favorite character to play as was a Dalish Elf because there are so many occassions where people are racist to you being a elf and you can reply like a total badass and its just mint.
I know I'm rambling but i could talk for hours about every single part of this game and it would be praise. it has passion that so few games have nowadays.
and this is all xbox stuff, on PC its even better, iv installed like 3 mods and its like re-living the amazing fantasy i love all over again. and not only that but without the mods it seems like they're more changes in dialog. and its interface and mechanics are different to xbox that make it more tactical and fun.

Just Understand that if you've played this game on a console in the past, get it again because it is a NEW and amazing experience . and if you've never played it, just trust that if you dont get it you will miss out on the best rpg EVER!

reviewText: Almost 6 years since this game was released, and it is still the best RPG out there. I was weary at first, but I cannot express how glad I am that I bought this game. The storyline was simply brilliant; I loved how I could choose to be an evil jerk who is rude to everyone, or be a heroic nobleman, and depending on what I did the whole outcome of the story was changed. Also, this game is filled with great cutscenes. As for the fighting, I didn't really like it at first, but it grew on me, and now I'd hate to have it any other way. The only downfalls were that after I finished the game, I felt empty, as if there was nothing as good worth living for anymore, and that when I made a second character and pursued the same romance as the first, I felt like I was cheating on my first character with the second :/\n\nThis is Bioware at it's finest. (Don't even bother with DA: 2 though. Thanks for rushing bioware and ruining it EA -_-)

reviewText:
It took me, admittedly, way too long to think of a good review for this game. I owned it on console before I managed to get it for PC, so I've had a fairly long experience with this game.

This was the first BioWare game I had ever played, and while it took me a while to get really into it (I didn't own it at first so I didn't have much time for immersion), it's one of my favorite games. You get to play as 16 different combinations of class, race, and gender, each personalizing your intro sequence and every interaction you get to be apart of in the game. Not to mention you get to make your Hero look however you wish to.

It may seem like a run of the mill 'save the world, kill some things' game, but it's a lot deeper than that. You're brought into a world where every choice you make has an affect on another aspect.

All in all, I love this game to bits, and while after playing the other games in the series it may get pretty tedious to play through Origins again, it's always nice to return to the roots of the franchise and see how far the series has come.

10/10

One of the best choice-based RPGs ever made.
The storyline is great, your character's origins make it easy to bond with him/her, as do the conversations with the companions.
There were many moments when I had to stand up and walk around the flat for few minutes before choosing a dialogue option because the choice was that hard and I knew it would influence the rest of the game.
I'm still kind of depressed after finishing it because I don't know what to do with myself now and I can't get over my sad ending.
Overall, epic story, nice gameplay, beautiful world, interesting side-quests, lovely companions and oh the feels.
10/10

reviewText:
Very quick review:
Well worth the money for a memorable RPG that can be played in so many ways. Fulfilling, funny, and completely engaging from start to finish. Minor flaws are forgivable and ignorable for the most part. Absolutely brilliant.

Slightly less quick review:
Pros:

+ Overall gameplay is fantastic – flaws are not overly bothersome.
+ Main storyline is excellent – very satisfying and great value for money in terms of length, involvement, and balance of fetch-type quests vs more intricate jobs.
+ Side quests are interesting and don’t feel like chores.
+ Character development is perfect – you’ll want to do those side quests!
+ Customisation: great choice of unique starting points and character builds makes for unrivalled replay value.
+ Incredible writing. Draws you in from the very start with whichever character build and story you’ve chosen and is genuinely hilarious at times.
+ Voice acting is fantastic.
+ Well-developed and immersive world build and lore, but not boring.
+ Decisions actually matter.
+ Great soundtrack.
+ Good mod support.

Cons:

- Graphics are a bit outdated – high settings or a couple of mods can help, but it’s not horrendous.
- Combat mechanics aren’t perfect – a bit slow at times and it takes some getting used to.
- You might cry a bit.
- You might also laugh till you pee a little.

Down to business:
Just as a starter, I adore this game. It’s one of my all-time favourites. The DA franchise is amazing, and although Origins is no spring chicken, it has aged well. On higher settings the game still has spectacular moments, graphically speaking, and the mid-low range settings are playable and artistically enjoyable, although not the best by any means. But you won’t care. At all.

If you’re looking for an entertaining, fulfilling, thoroughly immersive RPG with brilliant writing and touching character development, grab this. As someone who has also read the Dragon Age novels because she was desperate for more, I can tell you the world build is incredible – the lore is well structured, believable, and gripping. But for those of you who don’t want to read codex or journal entries, with this, you really don’t need to – you’ll be drawn in by the game itself, which expertly takes you through a robust storyline and gives you just the right amount of info to keep you interested without being boring or overwhelming.

Your companions will give you feels. Some you’ll hate, some will make you laugh, and some you’ll go full Hulk mode to protect.

As far as mechanics go, it’s not perfect – combat is a little slow and clunky at times, and it can take a little while to get used to. The multitude of tactical options and talent customisations available may be a little overwhelming to start with, especially if you’re not used to RPG builds. However, this is more than compensated for. Put simply, you can play whichever way you want. If you enjoy micromanaging and tactical play, the game deals very well with this. If you’d rather be more hands-on, or a mixture of both, go ahead – the AI is pretty good at letting your party get on with it while you smash some darkspawn skulls in with a sword as long as your own body, or go full mage-rage and burn someone to a crisp.

As for your actual character – the game does the (mostly) silent protagonist thing very well. It takes nothing away from the enjoyment of this game. The voice acting as a whole is excellent – very believable, very natural, and the right amount of comic relief vs. dramatic, feel-inducing bits. It’s all very epic but not over-acted.

The story customisation is second to none. At the start of the game, you can build your male or female character from scratch (or just use the presets) – human, elf, or dwarf; warrior, rogue or mage; noble or bottom of the pile - these options DO make a huge difference to the story. Replay value is amazing. You basically have multiple different games, and the choices you make as you progress shape the world around you as you deal with the Blight.

As far as DLC goes, Awakening is brilliant. You can take your story and character forward from the ending of Origins itself, or you can create another new one! It’s another good chunk of gameplay, with fantastic characters and plenty more to do.

The other extras are great value too – not to spoil anything, they’re perfect for those wanting a little more from certain characters, and are well worth the play time.

Moving forward to DA:2, you can take your Origins story along with you – yay for transferrable save files! Or you can custom-build a story if you weren’t exactly happy with your Origins playthrough and can’t be arsed to do another one. What more could you want?

Overall, DA:O is one of the best RPGs I’ve played to date. The characters, the world, and the general gameplay are too much fun to be dented by the flaws in mechanics. It’s something I will happily replay over and over again.

reviewText:
Dragon Age: Origins is a great game, and the Ultimate Edition is the way to go as it includes every single piece of DLC released for the game.

Everybody raves about this game, but rarely are the shortcomings addressed:

- Animations are dull and stiff (during both combat and dialogue)
- Character models have only a few different variations, (so you'll see the same haircuts etc. over and over again)
- The overall story arc is rather generic, (hey, you're the hero, go collect everyone and prepare for a final battle)
- Depending on what classes you play as, combat can be mind numbingly slow and weak (in particular for any ranged spec rogue, or sword/shield spec warrior)
- The world is kind of presented in a rather dull manner
- Several bugs (lots of crashing in Origins, and many other technical ones in Awakening)

Most of these issues can be ignored because of the other great content in the game. There are some intriguing side quests, interesting companion characters, tough decisions, there's loads replayability and the lore is really deep and well written. For me personally, most of the issues are fixed in Dragon Age II (though that game also brings forward some new issues...)

Overall, it's still a great game, I'd give it a flat 8.0/10. But again, for all the praise it gets, it's flaws are never talked about.
voteText: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
Grab your sword and shield because we're going on an adventure, First stop, Being born. Then we're off to fight rats in the kitchen, find your trusty mutt who turns out to be smarter than everyone else in the kingdom, seduce a visiting princess and head to bed where you're awoken by a siege to your castle. The rest of the game is a trudge across a wonderfully bland landscape dotted here and there by complete nonsense quests like Explore the dangerous swamp until you meet a sexy teenage witch who doesn't turn you into a frog. Kill ten gnolls along the way.
Racist stereotypes abound, as the only intentionally attractive male character has blonde hair and blue eyes and casts snarky comments the entire adventure, and you're introduced to the party's only black character by finding him naked, shackled in a cage and saying he belongs there. You have the option to free him and bring him as a servant if you go through a complicated back'n'forth with the village leader, who hates dark skin.

But in all seriousness this game is pretty chill, it's a 100+ hour modern day Baldur's Gate with decent characters, so if you're looking for another Baldur's Gate fix and don't have ADD you should consider this.

Mods that are must haves:
Advanced Tactics
Character Respec Mod
Detailed Tooltips
Madd Gift Guide + Awakening
Morrigan 3.3 and Leliana 2.8 (their default faces are fugly)
No Helmet Hack + Awakening (not a single good looking helm in this game)
Pretty Faces (NPC faces are fugly)
Skip the Fade Manual (don't even question this, this lets you skip the ♥♥♥♥♥iest part of the game)
Storage Chest (an official mod by a dev, that wasn't but into the game...)
Unlock 25 Tactic Slots Extended
v2 No more Snarling (shuts that damn dog up at the camp)

reviewText: Hi, do you like the Baldur's Gate series? What about Planescape: Torment? Icewind Dale? Mass effect with swords and deeper character interaction? Dragon Age: Origins was made by BioWare, the makers of Baldur's Gate, to be the spiritual successor to that very same Baldur's Gate. Imagine that! Spoiler Alert: They succeeded with that.  While not without it's minor flaws, Dragon Age: Origins has the deepest dialogue and interaction with NPC party members since... well, Baldur's Gate. It's not *as* deep as Baldur's Gate or Torment, but it is certainly deeper than Mass Effect. Anyone who enjoyed any of those games should play this. Oh, and don't play Dragon Age 2. It's crap, and was really dumbed down to be a straight console game rather than a PC RPG ported to console. It's really dull, so unless that's your thing just pass on the sequel.

reviewText:
Crashes and Freezes abound in this game. I remember having problems when originally trying to play the game in 2009 and for some reason it's worse with modern day (2014) hardware.

That aside, DA is a classic. A quick history: BioWare originally gained fame by creating isometric tactical RPGs in the Dungeons and Dragons (Forgotten Realms) setting. I never looked this up, but my guess is that some suit at Hasbro wasn't able to continue that relationship with BioWare (and ultimately Electronic Arts) and so they created their own setting to create a franchise around at or around which became the Dragon Age universe.

In contrast to the High Fantasy themes of Forgotten Realms, the campaign setting of Dragon Age is more Low Fantasy or Dark Fantasy. Magic is to be feared, the mood is dark and gritty, you are surrounded by despair and (to some degree) magic items are a little rare. Also in contrast to any D&D setting, characters do not seem to have direct relationships with gods (or Gods) and do not attain magical powers (i.e. healing) from them. In other words, there are healing schools in magic and no clerics.

Differences in the campaign aside, DA is EXACTLY what you would expect from a BioWare game. You have exactly the same viewpoint and controls as seen in Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, and Neverwinter. Interactions with NPCs and companions is exactly as you would see in Mass Effect (which is the natural extension of the previously mentioned games).

Lots of replay value is inherent with the different starting areas, different ways in which to approach quests and companions and multiple side quests. However, not NEARLY as much open endness within the world if you are to compare to a Bethesda, Elder Scrolls game. Multiple mods exist to enhance the game as well (check Nexus Mods)

DA is a classic RPG. Whether you like it or not, however, depends on your style of RPG. Obviously it's a single player game. It's not a JRPG. It's not as open as Elder Scrolls. Tactics are of moderate importance within encounters. Lots of scripted (voice acted) dialogue with NPCs with 'some' variation, but in the end moderately rail-roaded.

reviewText:
Dragon Age: Origins was made by Bioware almost 5 years ago already. This RPG is definitely good, but how good is it?

The visuals at times can be the worst part of the game. It is from 2009, and I hate comparing games unless I have a reason to. But I'm going to look at Mass Effect 1. The graphics were pretty nice in that game, but these visuals are just, wow. Describing it would be like describing the taste of soup to someone with no tongue. Although it is a bit more fit for a top-down view (which could explain the below average textures) it could've used some serious work in the third-person view. However, it isn't flat out awful like it may seem. In some places, the game looks gorgeous. This game doesn't really stand out in the graphics department, though.

The gameplay, is simply a click an enemy and use abilities type of game. But, it takes this format and adds more to it like the class trees, positioning of your party members, selecting party members, and even playing as them. If you're an action RPG fan, you will NOT like the combat. Well, to be honest, there are actually only a few action RPGs that actually had solid gameplay. In the end, you realize that the gameplay isn't the sharpest sword on the rack, but it's still actually very, very complex in a good way. A very good way.

The story is overused with the whole evil rising" thing to it. I'll use the Mass Effect trilogy as my victim again- I mean my "example" again. Heh

reviewText:
I count Dragon Age: Origins amongst my favourite roleplaying games ever made. I've played through it at least four times on console, and then some. A perfect combination of old and new, Origins appeals to fans of RPGs old and new.

The game itself plays out like your typical Dungeons & Dragons inspired affair, with a wide variety of skills, attributives and abilities that govern the outcome of multiple scenarios. Though the combat animations can be a bit sluggish and dull, winning fights takes some degree of cunning and strategy, especially on the higher difficulties. More than any other game I've seen, this one takes managing your party to a whole new level. For fans of strategy games, this game will more than satisfy your inner tactician with its myriad of planning options for each and every consistency.

You pick from the standard three classes: rouge, warrior and mage. However, the more open-ended structure of the leveling system allows for a lot more nuance and depth than your average dice roller. For example, on my second playthrough, I decided to be a mage. And whilst being a mage in this game is the most fun I've ever had as a mage in any game, I still prefer the path of the warrior. With a couple specialisations that I unlocked in the game, I was able to craft a battlemage that fit my tastes perfectly, capable of rushing foes down with a battleaxe and heavy armours and able to switch to a fireball or living bomb spell for crowd control seamlessly.

Though the setting is extremely derivative, the world's politics and inner working still manage to be intriguing with plenty of rich lore to back it up. However, it's not the world that makes exploring Thedas on your quest to save the world from an army of orcs and an evil dragon interesting. It's the characters.

For those familiar with [/i]Mass Effect[/i] will find themselves very comfortable with how [/i]Dragon Age: Origins[/i] treats party members, perhaps even more so. For almost your entire crew, you almost always have the option to kick them out, kill them or otherwise refuse your help (though you'd have to be some kind of hardcore maniac to do this). Most of them are romancable, and all of them are colourful, multi-dimensional people with their own interests, backstory, agendas and quirks. This is where making moral" choices becomes difficult. Instead of any kind of morality meter
date: each of your followers have an approval rating with you. When considering your actions
recommended: you'll have to keep satisfying your party in mind as well.\n\nAnd the choices. Oh man

It's an epic albeit cliche-riddled journey as you unite the land and raise an army strong enough to face a horde of monsters and the demonic dragon that leads them. Sound familiar? Does it sounds like every fantasy game you'd ever played? Dragon Age: Origins is anything but original

reviewText: Like everything that's not Dragon Age but better, being Dragon Age and all.

Dragon Age: Origins is BioWare at its finest. With an amazing story and great characters it is a worthy successor to one of the all time greats: Baldur's Gate. At a 30€ price point or 7.49€ during sales the Ultimate Edition is amazing value with easily over 100 hours of gameplay.

In DA:O you step into the shoes of a Grey Warden, an ancient order of warriors created to defend Thedas from the Darkspawn, during the start of the Fifth Blight. The main story takes you through the kingdom of Ferelden as you gather various forces and companions to aid you in your goal of defeating the Archdemon and ending the Blight. The various parts of the main story introduce you to the political struggles and various races and groups such as dwarves, elves and mages and can be done in a non-linear fashion. The storylines are great and have multiple branching paths to them. Where the game shines is the dialogue and interaction with NPCs and companions in particular, you have a well written and interesting group of followers with various backgrounds and goals that you get to explore through the events of the game. The massive amount of lore to explore and find out about through codex entries and dialogues with characters is very impressive, especially when you take into account that this is the first game in a series set in an original universe created by BioWare.

From a gameplay perspective DA:O is a classic CRPG: Real-time hotkey based combat with a strategic top-down view and the option to pause the game and set up your and your parties moves. The combat will definitely appeal to people who liked games like Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale and other RPGs of the late 90s and early 2000s. There's a wide variety of active and passive abilities unique to each class and their specializations.

Visually the game was a bit dated already when it came out, if it is to be judged by graphical fidelity. The game doesn't look as good as many more modern titles, but it definitely doesn't damage the experience. The art style and design on the other hand is mostly very good and stays realistic with the armour and weapon designs. There are both brown landscapes such as the towns and their surrounding areas and lush forests and vibrant vistas.

The soundtrack by Inon Zur is great and really sets the mood well with great compositions. The quality of the voice actors is very good and the casting is great with talented people such as Claudia Black and Tim Curry putting in amazing performances.

All of the downloadable content is included in the Ultimate Edition which makes it the most ideal purchase over the only slightly cheaper base game. The expansion pack 'Awakening' comes close to capturing the feel of the main game and gives the player an additional 20+ hours of gametime. the DLCs themselves vary a lot in quality and range in length from 30 minutes to a few hours and none of them are really stellar. Despite this they are worth playing since they come at such a low bundled price and give you insight into various characters and aspects of the lore of the universe.

Dragon Age: Origins is a must have for any RPG fan and I truly recommend it to any gamer, at least at this low price point.

A great RPG especially in this version. This game has an interesting combat system that requires, a mix of tactics and strategy, in order for you to succeed.

Pros
-Great Combat system.
-Interesting world combined with a well told story
-Story changes depending on your own decisions.
-Relationships with the other party members influence the story, as well as improving their attributes.
-Multiple classes and races, each with their own origin story.
-Large replay value
-All DLC in this game, for a lower price than purchasing them independently.
- Vast amount of content (82 hours for one playthrough including all the DLC).
Cons
- Can be glitchy at times, paticularly in the Awakening DLC. I.E Vigilance bug or the ending cutscene loop.
- Can be too easy at times, paticularly at the end of the game, if you completed most of the sidequests, obtaining the best equipment.
- Graphics could be better, but mods can improve them. Also it really isn't too much of an issue, as the game is old.
- Does require a large amount of time to complete, so not for those that get bored quickly.
The last great classic RPG from Bioware, worth playing.

Having said all of that, this is easily in my top 5 games of all time. I love the story line and how in depth it can get with desicions, and the desicions actually matter in dragon age, they affect quests, what people (mainly your party) think of you, and change the ending. The combat can be a little slow and clunky at times, but this doesnt really deter me. I prefer the big hot bar of spells and talents to the button mash system that is implemented in many newer RPGs (dragon age 2). Dragon Age: Origins sets itself apart from other games of it's genre.  The story is phenomenal to say the least, the characters are some of the deepest, well-thought figures in any game I've ever played, and the RPG element allows the player direct decisions on nearly every aspect of the game.  When 'epic, fantasy RPG' comes to mind, DA:O is truly the elite in it's class.  The Ultimate Edition is no exception, great price for value.

I'm a long time console player with probably several hundred hours and atleast 5 playthroughs, but I have yet to complete my first playthrough of the game and all the DLC on the PC yet and already have 80+ hours logged.  You heard correctly; 80+ hours on one character and I've only completed the base game, Warden's Peak, Stone Prisoner, and Golem's of Amgarrak.  I have yet to complete Awakening, Witch Hunt, Leliana's Song, and Darkspawn Invasion.  I expect the total hours to be 120+ on one character by the time I have done everything the Ultimate Edition has to offer.  Easily one of the best values for dollar per hour spent.

The combat may be the only draw-back to the game.  Strategy-wise, it's extremely in-depth and requires much preparation on higher difficulties.  Veteran MMO players will feel right at home.  However the visuals are lacking (keeping in mind the date of release) and the whole system isn't very 'exhilarating', though you'll feel the occasional rush during a boss fight.  The combat serves its purpose and doesn't really throw any curves; it doesn't add much noteworthy additions to the game, but it certainly does not detract from the piece.

The vanilla game is stellar in itself, but the incorporation of the DA Updater allows easy organization of mods.  Mods I've found especially good include textures, re-skins, graphics, combat AI, and combat tactics.

Overall, one of the best modern RPG's in existence.  Give it a shot if you haven't, you won't regret it.

Dragon Age is one of those few games that genuinely lives up to the hype. The atmosphere, characters, voicework, setting, and overall gameplay serve to place it in the top tier of games in general (and RPGs specifically). Though one could justifiably nitpick about certain tactical options that don't work, dialog/script triggers that don't function, and quests that don't resolve, ultimately it would all be just that - nitpicking. DA:O is one of my favorite games of all time.  It has an engaging storyline, and the ability to communicate with your teammates is highly satisfying.  While some games claim that your decisions matter, most end up the same regardless, but I LOVE the way this game actually makes me feel like my decisions are affecting the world.  The different difficulty settings can appeal to hardcore or casual gamers, and with all the different classes and specializations, it is good for many different playthroughs.

Dragon Age: Origins - Ultimate Edition is an exceptional and epic fantasy role playing game.  It is a perfect combination of old school  (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, etc...) and modern western rpgs.  It has a rich universe that tries to differentiates itself from the usual Tolkien bases (though I believe it is still very close to the classics...  Replace Darkspawns with evil Orcs, and Archdemon with Sauron...  But that is not a turn off at all...)

The tactical gameplay is very fun, the player is at the center of the story line and the many dialogues make you actually care about the other characters and NPCs.  There are several important choices that significantly change the story line.  I am curious to know what's Bioware's canon for this game.  Last but not least, this Ultimate Edition has all the DLCs and I really enjoyed most of them (Awakening is a respectable +20 hours campaign).

I will definitely miss the epic tale of my Grey Warden but I am also looking forward to discover the story of Hawke and the Inquisitor (DA2 & 3)!  I wish they were available on Steam, but hey, you can't have everything, haha!

Verdict: A+

Oh God, what can you say about DA:O? It was already one of the greatest RPGs of recent years, swapping console button-mashing with tactical, challenging combat, and throwing in a compelling story, fantastic world-building and excellent characers to boot. Now with the very active modding community, it's even better. It still looks great, plays great, and manages to unfold some pretty extensive lore without ever being overbearing. Plus, you get a dog!\n\nWorth it for pretty much any price, but the Ultimate Edition is regularly in sales for less than a fiver. You've no reason not to buy it.

One of my favorit RPG's out there, you get to chose from 3 different races, Human, Dwarf and 2 different types of Elf's, The Dalish (wood elf's) and City Elf's (Elf who are living in the human city slums).
After you get to chose their Origin, this can differ from being a Noble born, or being a born of a lower class, each has it's effect on the story you play, and the game, giving a great reason to replay the game multiple times.
You then chose a class, you can pick 1 out of 3 choices, Warriro, rogue and mage, but this does not mean you have to be fx, a warrior with a sword and shield, you get to chose how you want to play your class, and what role you want to be in your group, of up to 4 members at a time.

The combat is real time, with a pause function so you can select a individual hero / companion and make them do a precise action. This makes gives the combat alot of strategy, and makes it alot of fun.
The leveling up system is pretty standart, you get to assing points into Strenght, Endurance, Willpower and so on, pretty standart from other RPG's.

Through out the game you will meet different companions, and you get to make your own group as you see fit. This brings up the strategy again, you can make your group as you see fit, you can go all berzerk and go with 4 damage dealers, or you can even it all out, and have a tank, healer and 2 damage dealers, kinda like you own little WoW dungeon group.
One neat feature is you get to have actual conversations with them, and they have different personalitys, and you can earn affection points with each and every one of them. At some point's, your companions will even backstap you, if they don't like you enough.

The story in the game is great, you are a Grey Warden, the defenders of the Realm against the Dark Spawn. A race made up of monsters, demons and all that evil ♥♥♥♥, who is led by the Arch Demon ( A giant ♥♥♥ dragon ! ), you have to help the realm by gathering an army from different factions through the world, to fight the Dark Spawn horde, els all will be lost.
Im not going to say much more on the story, but it is one of the best features of this game. The very best being YOU GET TO DECIDE HOW ITS ALL GOING TO PLAY OUT, your choices matter in the game, and will have consequenses later on.

Over all DA:O is a great time, there is so much to do, and you get hundres of hours worth of gameplay. The main game is fantastic, and I'd surgest only getting the DLC if you really like the game, but even the DLC is worth it. They give you a good 3-5 hours worth of content, maybe abit more. Overall the DLC is cool, buy them if you like the game, they are like springels on a already awesome Sunday Ice Cream.

Now the expansion on the other hand, is not really worth it. The story is pretty boring, it ends just as it gets interesting, and it dosnt really feel as epic, as the standart game does. The Story starts a few months after completing the main games story, you are now the Grey Warden commander, and you have to remake the Grey Wardens, by getting new people to become Grey Wardens, as said it sounds pretty cool, but in the end it is a very boring story and kind of lazy written. It's just not as good as the main story.
The Expansion got some cool features, like cool looking armors, a new level cap, and some other nice things.
Sure it's some hours worth of gameplay, but overall id say it's not really worth it. It feels tagged on and I would only recomend it, if you can get your hands on the Dragon Age : Origins - Ultimate Edition.

I enjoyed the hell out of DA:O - Ultimate Edition, and I would highly recommend this game to anyone who likes RPG's.

I bought this purely because of Dragon Age: Inquisition but DA: Origins is a great game that with a few mods looks great. I highly recommend the ultimate edition, forget the deluxe edition, and forget vanilla pay the extra money for the ultimate edition. It adds greatly to your Dragon Age experience and works well with Bioware's Dragon Age keep. At an easy setting you will run through the game in about 48 hours, but with 6 character origins options and 3 unique classes you'll come back for more.
The game also has strict consequences to actions - like The Witcher series more than The Elder Scrolls - so choose wisely. If you are into role playing your CRPG characters then DA: Origins is a solid option with its racial, gender and class options.
In terms of mods I also recommend downloading Bioware's own graphics update for  the Qunari race[social.bioware.com]. I also highly recommend using DAO-Modmanager by Altorian (this is a must have if you want to mod the game) and Dragon Age Redesigned by Dracomies and Extra Dog Slot by Dheuster. I run two or three other graphics/texture mods but to my mind these mods are necessary.
All in all I highly recommend DA: Origins even if it’s 5 years old. There are a few glitchy aspects to the controls but nothing major. This is a tactical combat game not an action hack and cast adventure. Like Final Fantasy or older CRPGs you’re managing a party but with the added twist of favour points which will determine whether your companions stay with you or not (although in my experience you can easily manipulate their favour at lower difficult settings to “adore” ratings by gifting regularly.
If you don’t like Dungeons and Dragons (DnD) inspired game systems or DnD/Tolkienesque fantasy races then this is not a game for you. Dragon Age is steep in the stock of fantasy tropes, the undead (Dark Spawn), dragons, mages, rogue, dwarves who live under mountains, demons and god-like dragons (don’t think just because you’re the chosen one you take a dragon on single-handed this is very definitely not Skyrim).  However if you do like DnD and do like the stock fantasy tropes Dragon Age: Origins offers an engaging storyline with good graphics and good tactical combat system.
As a backstory to DA: Inquisition Origins is a good buy, but even as a stand alone game Origins fares well as a tactical combat DnD inspired game. A solid 3 out of 5
One of the best RPG's in my book!
after playing for 100+ hours, I conclude that I like it.

If you're like me and like to complete games in order and are considering playing this before Dragon Age: Inquisition, do it!!!\n\nI can't believe how much I loved this game! It may be old and the graphics may show that a little, but surprisingly it does still hold up and is easy to look past. The characters are all amazing, it was painful to have to choose only 3 to follow you each mission, because I wanted to spend time with them all! I felt like the whole world was alive and I was part of it. The combat is pretty challenging, but it's rewarding when you plan out your attacks and powers in the correct combination to interact with each other and cause the maximum damage. This game is so worth playing!

Possibly the best game I've ever played. It has some bugs so some missions cannot be finished, and the UI and controls take some getting used to, Also, the learning curve is quite steep so you need to level your characters carefully and plan ahead. But the atmosphere more than makes up for any problems/glitches I have found. I have really felt like being part of the story all along the way. The characters and their background stories are great, voice acting is superb (in particular Claudia Black and Geraldine Blecker). And the whole game has an incredible sense of humor: I spent long hours playing the jailbreak scene over and over again to see the various plotlines for that part as well as tried different groups of companions to hear the different ways the characters mock each other.
An fun Role play game.
The Ultimate RPG
9.5\nAnd that's the bottom line!

Dragons Age is well a put together RPG that will immerse you in the story and you will invest time in developing the characters that accompany you on your quest. The biggest downside to the game is the story is tried, tired and done a thousand times over. You the hero are on quest to destroy the dark spawn that is wreaking havoc on the land. This being its biggest downfall does not make this a bad game at all. I had over 40+ hours in one play through and with all the decision making you encounter this game will surely keep you amused for multiple plays. One of the best combat systems I've seen you can not only setup the AI to have your companions on the quest do what you like but you can fully take control of them which in my opinion is a huge advantage. The combat system is a little bit of learning curve but once you get the hang of it you will love it and enjoy the simpleness of how your characters act and follow your directions in the heat of some best battles you will see in an RPG. Bioware did an excellent job in creating a game you can fully plunge yourself into and get behind.

It's amazing that this game still is one of the best games of its genre, if not The best.

Intriguing story, not too shabby graphics, fun and unique combat, good variety of difficulty levels, some very interesting/funny characters and, for the most part, good voice acting(something i find very rare).

The few flaws in some areas are definitely made up for by other parts of the game.
And with some mods you can improve this already amazing game even more!
one of the best RPG game i ever played.......

Well, what more is there to say than: This is, by far, one of the best RPG's of all time. It's well able to keep up to classic's like Baldurs Gate or Diablo. I would considers this the best modern RPG there is on the market. The story is great, the gameplay can be very challenging. Be aware if you don't like to read or immerse yourself in the game though, there is a lot of dialogue and things to read; wether you like that is up to you. Your small team that you build up over time, is great. Everyone has a great background story, wether it be Zevran from the Crows of Antiva or Alistair as (almost) former Templar. The world is big; there are many factions that you can read about. The Chantry, The Crows of Antiva, The Circle (of Magi). For those who can't get enough, there are many sidequests which are optional, but give you a good way of earning some gold.\n\nOverall the game is a clear 10/10 for me, a must play. I don't give this rating to every game I see.
