My favorite RPG of all time.  You manage a whole team of characters and choose 4 to venture out with to complete quests and explore.  You actually have to use tactics and correct positioning to succeed which really makes the environment you fight in extremely important (leeroy jenkins tatics do not apply).  Lots of customization in terms of character abilities (multiple advanced classes to choose from) and armors/weapons to wear.  You can also change up your team compisition to create new and exciting gameplay options.  The story is not the greatest but does feel epic at times, the gameplay is what makes this game so good. If Bioware have proven anything it's that they can make excellent RPGs, and Dragon Age: Origins is definitely one of their good ones. Dragon Age... Dragon Age... Dragon Age... Where to begin? Well this game was made in 2009 (I think), so giving that it's around 4-5 years old, It's pretty fun to play. The main story is not only vast, but intense as you're protecting the realm, nay the human population from the inevitable Blight as the ever popular hero among the 'Grey Wardens'.
The combat system isn't too shabby, and the leveling up system (Skill tree) is pretty neat also. The main thing which does it for me however (like the Mass Effect series), is the dialogue. You can even level up your coercion skill which provides 'intimidate' and 'persuade' options during dialogue cutscenes.
Along with the fact that the campaign is amazing, there are HUNDREDS of side quests (as expected) to achieve!
Now so far, this review has been based upon 'Dragon Age: Origins', yet I feel I should also take a moment to talk about it's expansion 'Awakening'...
Other than additional DLC for this game (Wardens Keep, The Stone Prisoner etc) Dragon Age: Awakening opens up yet another vast campaign which continues from 'Origins'. This places your main character (which can be imported over from a previous save, or created from level 20) into what becomes Vigils Keep, the home of the Grey Wardens. You soon discover that although the Blight has been prevented and the Archdemon killed, Darkspawn are still at large and taking orders from someone, or something...

Cutting this review short, whether you buy this game (preferably the Ultimate Edition with all DLCs) in a sale or not, you will not be disappointed.
You will however, be disappointed if you play Dragon Age 2, which I will not get started on...

Overall, 8-9 / 10!

A very long, but excellent game overall. Aside from the Elder Scrolls series, I don't know any games that will give you more bang for your buck than Dragon Age (: Origins - Ultimate Edition). If you go through all the DLC and finish most of the sidequests in the game you'll easily spend over 100 hours on a single run, and there were hardly any points in the game where I felt like the plot was starting to drag.

The gameplay is good overall. I do think the strategy elements were sometimes a bit tedious though. I didn't like pausing battles every 0.5 seconds to give all of my characters new orders and it was also difficult sometimes to get my characters to do exactly what I wanted them to, when I wanted them to. The AI is not as bad as in Mass Effect 1, but I still often had to deal with things like my ranged fighter throwing herself into melee combat rather than keeping distance and my assassin attacking enemies head on rather than trying to backstab. The game does provide you with Tactics slots to tell your characters in advance how to respond to situations in battle, but that takes a lot of time to set up and doesn't always give good results.

As with most BioWare games (KOTOR, Mass Effect), they've put a lot of effort into developing the main characters and giving them intruiging backstories. However, in Dragon Age I feel like they've even taken it a few steps further. Each individual character gets lots of 'screen time' (if you bother to talk to them) and the romance sidequest has been worked out a lot more than in their previous games. One of the gameplay elements is a 'relationship' system that will make choices you make during the game affect your relationship with your party members. A good relationship will make characters befriend you or fall in love with you (revealing more of the character's backstory), a bad relationship might make the character leave the party permanently. Personally, I really loved this and wish more RPGs had this.

What I particularly loved about this game is that the choices that you face during the development of the plot aren't always as straightforward as picking a good or bad option. You will face plenty of dillemmas in which it is not so obvious what the outcome of your choices will be and you'll feel compelled to apply your own moral reasoning to the situation. In the end, this makes it feel more like you're actually playing as yourself (or a realistic human being) and not someone who's putting up a goody-two-shoes / bad-♥♥♥ act.

Anyway, I enjoyed Dragon Age a lot. I think it will please any fan of the RPG genre. It's a very well-made game overall that is more than worth the €7,50 I paid for it during the Sale.

Dragon Age Origins is a beautiful RPG game with a not-so-unique overarcing plot with many subplots sprinkled in between. The characters are alive and full of their own personality and own agendas. Great combat system, though it takes a while to get the hang of it.\n\nPlus you get a dog and you can ride into battle with him. (not on him unfortunately but that'd be cool. I'm sure a mod exists for that)

This is actually the first RPG I ever played, and I absolutely love it. I still play it over and over again, because there are so many possibilites for you to choose from and I found the storyline very engrossing. Very enjoyable and entertaining, I would recommend it to everyone.

This game is very rich in story! You befriend many on your quest to save Fereldan and destroy the blight, each character has a very unique and rich background. Your choice of race, personal background, along with your actions, bleed into the story shaping it into tragic, sweet, or heroic ending. I definitely recommend this to anyone who enjoys a good solid game where the outcome is entirely up to you. Easily one of my favorites!
I romanced a hot elf and then I died riding a dragon which is really how I want my real life to go

This game was like a great book you just can't put down until you finish. And when it did finish I was left satisfied yet wanting more. A truly immersive experience, I found myself talking to my companions, and laughing at their bickering. It features a great storyline with a different outcome depending on your choices. There is a bit of a morale system in that certain companions will like or dislike your actions and you will gain or lose reputation with them. Some companions have different morals than others so you can choose to take those who will agree with your choices and thus gain rep with them. However for the most part you'll want to choose your companions based on what classes/spells you need for battles. This game can be brutally hard with battles, but it does have a difficulty option which can be changed at any time.

If you're a fan of RPG's this is a must-play. It features immersive towns and people, all of which have something to do or say. The world is full and rich, with no empty" spots.

However
recommended: so if you skip something you may not be able to go back later if you go forward in the main quest. Side quests are aplenty as are companions. You may struggle with bag space as you never know what you might need. I got around this by avoiding the crafting specialisations and selling the materials. This left room for all the loot.\n\nAll in all
hoursPlayed: I'd give this a 9.5/10. Very few RPG's come close to this immersive experience."

reviewText: A true Bioware classic! Get the Ultimate Edition for all the cool/hilarious DLC.

Kind of reminds me of the old Baldurs Gate Series (yeah, I'm THAT old, lol).  It starts slow, but it gets good on into the game.  Haven't finished it yet, but I'm enjoying the ride so far.  As an artist, the dull colors are annoying.  Everyone used to joke about everything in Quake being the same color, its the same idea.  Everything in DAO is a dull shade of either brown or grey, with some red blood splatter for highlights.\n\nOverall, I'd give it a 3.5 stars out of 5, definitely worth playing!
its great
Great game the sequel is BAD!!!

I'm not sure why it took me so long to get into this game before, but it was certainly worth the effort to do it this time around.

The story is old Bioware quality with as many engaging characters as you'd like, ready to be invested in and loved or hated.  The story keeps a nice pace that doesn't leave you tired (except Orzammar; that started getting a little old), and has an ending that gives you some real choices that change the outcome dramatically.  The DLC for this game (comes with Ultimate, no need to purchase) is equally as well done and equally as engaging, with some nice rewards.

Combat may be my biggest gripe in this game, but there are enough abilities to keep it feeling fresh for a while.  Zooming all the way out to make it a top-down strategy RPG helped the experience dramatically, but by the end of the game, I'd felt it started to get a little long in the tooth.  The animations are somewhat lacking, however, which can sometimes make combat boring to watch.  Managing healing and stamina/mana expenditure usually will keep you pretty engaged, however.

All in all, I think Dragon Age is a great example of Bioware's quality and commitment to their product during their highest point.  I hope that their games in the future will return to this level of fidelity and aesthetic, and continue to engage the player on multiple levels.

One of the best RPGs I have ever played. Story is great, character development is spot on and decisions you make have consequences later on. I remember buying the DLC at full price and still not feeling ripped off. Really good game!

Really awesome RPG with a ton of things to do. Reminiscent of the KOTOR series with the ability to pause mid-fight to asses the battlefield. Cool art direction and design. I like that you can bang some of the characters :)\n\n10/10

Its awesome! The combat is alittle rough around the edges in my opinion, but I love everything else. The story is nice, your party members are awesome and have so much life to them. Also if you wanna increase the fun, you can put in some nice mods to make things even better. So to cut it short, you're getting your moneys worth.

The best rpg I've played so far. I played it back in 2009 when it came out and that resulted with a couple of forgotten months through two playthroughs. Two tumbs up for this. Much better than the sequel. Now the only hope that remains is that they don't mess up inquisition ;).
The best game ever made! - unique feel with 4 characters to play with in the same time(almost :) )\nGreat story and graphics!!!

If you're like me and like to complete games in order and are considering playing this before Dragon Age: Inquisition, do it!!!\n\nI can't believe how much I loved this game! It may be old and the graphics may show that a little, but surprisingly it does still hold up and is easy to look past. The characters are all amazing, it was painful to have to choose only 3 to follow you each mission, because I wanted to spend time with them all! I felt like the whole world was alive and I was part of it. The combat is pretty challenging, but it's rewarding when you plan out your attacks and powers in the correct combination to interact with each other and cause the maximum damage. This game is so worth playing!

Possibly the best game I've ever played. It has some bugs so some missions cannot be finished, and the UI and controls take some getting used to, Also, the learning curve is quite steep so you need to level your characters carefully and plan ahead. But the atmosphere more than makes up for any problems/glitches I have found. I have really felt like being part of the story all along the way. The characters and their background stories are great, voice acting is superb (in particular Claudia Black and Geraldine Blecker). And the whole game has an incredible sense of humor: I spent long hours playing the jailbreak scene over and over again to see the various plotlines for that part as well as tried different groups of companions to hear the different ways the characters mock each other.

Dragon Age: Origins - Ultimate Edition is an exceptional and epic fantasy role playing game.  It is a perfect combination of old school  (Baldur's Gate, Icewind Dale, etc...) and modern western rpgs.  It has a rich universe that tries to differentiates itself from the usual Tolkien bases (though I believe it is still very close to the classics...  Replace Darkspawns with evil Orcs, and Archdemon with Sauron...  But that is not a turn off at all...)

The tactical gameplay is very fun, the player is at the center of the story line and the many dialogues make you actually care about the other characters and NPCs.  There are several important choices that significantly change the story line.  I am curious to know what's Bioware's canon for this game.  Last but not least, this Ultimate Edition has all the DLCs and I really enjoyed most of them (Awakening is a respectable +20 hours campaign).

I will definitely miss the epic tale of my Grey Warden but I am also looking forward to discover the story of Hawke and the Inquisitor (DA2 & 3)!  I wish they were available on Steam, but hey, you can't have everything, haha!

Verdict: A+

Amazing game! Deep story line, memorable characters and good combat for its age is one of the best RPG games I have ever played. There is a lot of exploration and many quests with interesting loot. The characters are funny, interesting, and you can also romance them and import your save to Dragon Age 2 so you can play with the decisions you made. Decisions in this game are very important, you practically create your own story and by being different races and classes you get different beginnings and people react differently depending on your race and class. This is truly a piece of art and well worth your money for $30 you can look at 100+ hours in this game. Totally recommend it

I bought this game in the summer sale 2014 when it was on 75% off, If i had known what this game was like then, I would of happily paid the full price for this absolute gem of a game, This is by far one of the best computer games I have ever played, The combat took me a little while to get use to, but once you do it is so enjoyable, the storyline is enjoyable, the content appears to be huge which is never a bad thing, the replay value is incredible to as each game and different way to achieve goals,  I would recommend this game to anyone and if you have not played this game, i highly recommend you do so!

A+

With dialogue options that determine storyline and character outcomes and a combat system which allows you to manage and direct each party member individually (which is essential for group cohesion and maximum effectiveness) this is by far one of the best RPG's that I've played. The voice acting is one of the best I've seen in a game, not to mention party members converse with each other independent of the player controlling them resulting in entertaining and humorous banter while you explore. An amazing addition that I enjoyed the whole way through as it changes with each combination of characters you elect to your party. The cutscenes do not take away from gameplay, rather they aid in making the story more cinematic.

Pros -
- Good story
- Well-rounded combat system with party tactics, allowing player to manage all members as they see fit.
- Dialogue choices affect outcome of relationships between player and companions as well as quests and storyline.
- Incredible voice acting for all characters (except the player, whose character does not speak).
- Professions and skills can affect combat and dialogue options.
- Character background choices determine one of many intros to the main game making replay value more worthwhile than just builing a new spec.

Cons -
- Maps seem a bit limited in exporability.
- Character background, while providing variety, has only minor impact on game outcome, but interaction throughout is noticeably different.

Overall: One of my top ten games. I definitely recommend this game to anyone who enjoys both RPG and fantasy.

Bioware once again comes at you with a streamlined RPG story that'll rip through that chainmail straight to your heart. Slightly linear, but ever engaging. Combat system is a bit slow, but for fans who love character interaction and choice-based gameplay, Dragon Age's fantasy elements deliver quite nicely.

Dragon Age Origins would be considered a spiritual successor to the late and great Bioware RPG known as Baldurs Gate. Both share a similar style of game play and similar style of story and design, though Dragon Age is far superior in terms of production value from its much older cousin-game Baldurs Gate. From amazing graphics (that still stand against most of todays games), to a compelling story line (that can be nearly fully customized despite the obvious fact it has to end), the music and even the sound effects - everything is crisp, clean, easy to run and not too hardware intensive.\n\nSet aside a few hours a week if you want to play this fast paced tactical RPG, you won't regret it.

Dragon Age is one of those few games that genuinely lives up to the hype. The atmosphere, characters, voicework, setting, and overall gameplay serve to place it in the top tier of games in general (and RPGs specifically). Though one could justifiably nitpick about certain tactical options that don't work, dialog/script triggers that don't function, and quests that don't resolve, ultimately it would all be just that - nitpicking. A worthy addition to the library of all RPG fans.

DA:O is one of my favorite games of all time.  It has an engaging storyline, and the ability to communicate with your teammates is highly satisfying.  While some games claim that your decisions matter, most end up the same regardless, but I LOVE the way this game actually makes me feel like my decisions are affecting the world.  The different difficulty settings can appeal to hardcore or casual gamers, and with all the different classes and specializations, it is good for many different playthroughs.
The last great classic RPG from Bioware, worth playing.

reviewText: The best.\n\nNo, really! This is the best game I've ever played in my life!

One of the best games I've ever played, the storyline and the World of Thedas is rich and entertaining, as well as immensely fun. Your companions are all intriguing in their own ways and I've played the game so many times just to experience the world over and over.\n\n10/10.

DA:O is an incredibly fun tactical squad-based RPG. The story is solid and character decisions make a HUGE difference, especially as you can import your save from DA:O into Dragon Age 2, and then into Dragon Age: Inquisition. The gameplay is just as strong, featuring a simple, easy-to-use dialogue system and a robust combat system, replete with AI tactics which can somewhat automate the process of managing 4 characters in a combat environment.\n\nTL;DR - If you like RPG games with meaningful player decisions (e.g., not what Skyrim does with meaningless player decisions) and don't mind an over-the-shoulder/bird's-eye-view approach to a tactically-grounded squad-based combat game, then this is the game for you!
One of the best RPGs of our time

Honestly I'm reviewing this more for the extra content the core game itself. I had already played dragon age before but none of the dlcs or awakening. Dragon age is a fantastic game for those who enjoy fantasy rpgs with turn based fighting. The world is beautiful, the story is detailed, the characters are colorful and a long game to enjoy every single moment. If you like the Kotor games then you'd like this. The DLC's were fun but as normal they are quite short. You have Leilana's song to learn about her background. Darkspawn invasion allowes you to enjoy being a darkspawn. Shale is a great add on character. Return to Ostagar and Wardens keep are decent small maps. Awakening is very well done with tons of new skills. Witch hunt is decent but short. The Golems of Angnarok is good but the final boss is way to hard in my opinion. All in all, a great series and I had a ton of fun replaying again. Fantasy RPGs are my all time favorites and this one will be included there.

Very good game.  I did a full playthrough of the base game, DLC, and expansion when I had it for the PS3.  A very cool story, good combat.  You can also pause the game to tell your characters what to do in advance, if you're not able to keep up with the combat normally.  It's a pretty challenging game, and it has a ton of content even without the DLC and expansion.  The character customization I feel could've been a bit better but it's good enough.  Meet lots of interesting characters, and travel around with 3 other characters of your choosing as you meet them along the way.\n\nAt times you will have to make some important decisions, which is always fun to see in a game.  Things that happen in this game are supposed to change the world of Dragon Age 2, though from what I have heard Dragon Age 2 was a big dissapointment.  Still, this is worth playing.  One of the best out there!

Where to begin, my hours do not reflect the time I have played this on non-steam copy and Xbox 360. This game, I love it and I love everything about it. The choices seem meaningful, the combat is great and the standalone addition adds some real content to the game without you feeling like someone has torn your arm off.

Would I recommend this game? In a heart beat, I would normally write a pros Vs cons list but I know the pros would FAR outweight any cons. I suppose you could call me a Dragon Age fan boy, but it has earned that distinction.

An amazing RPG very similar to KOTOR. save the world from darkspawn, basically orcs from LOTR.  Choose one of six origin stories to start your game and become the hero of ferelden.

3 classes to choose from
many different skills to learn through leveling up, and plenty of different party members to recruit as well.

If you are a fan of RPGs, do yourself a favor and get this game.

Dragon Age: Origins remains as one of the best fantasy roleplaying games in existence. Everything vital to a successful RPG is present: a quality character progression system, a gripping and immersive storyline, fantastic music, ambience, and sound effects, supremely developed and dynamic characters, and an actively enjoyable combat system. This game provides an exceptionally entertaining experience (with an estimated forty hours of gameplay) with tremendous replay value, as there are a variety of alternative choices you may decide throughout the game's nonlinear epic. For any fan of RPGs or fantasy, Dragon Age is a necessity!\n\nFor some background information, you'll be able to select from several Origins (three races: human, elf, and dwarf) and be conscripted into an order known as the Grey Wardens, hunters of creatures known as Darkspawn. As a Grey Warden, you will observe a period of Blight in which an Archdemon, the highest member of the caste of darkspawn, is present. Though a Blight occurs, you will face several political challenges as the entire country of Ferelden is in turmoil. You and your band of party members will have the combat this threat yourself. The story is ultimately highly intriguing.

I've played it over and over again before buying it on steam. Imo this is one of the best games I've played. From time to time when I hear a melody or noice or something that reminds me of Dragon Age, and I have to play it again, cause its so good! <3

Even 6 years after the release, this game remains a genre-defining RPG. I could not recommend it more. I had trouble getting into it at first, but once past the origin story, the epic scope of the game comes into view. Incredible story, great characters, real decision-making and tactical strategy comes into play, and I could not recommend this game more. It's fantastic.

Dragon Age: Origins is my favourite RPG, personally. It may have aged a little over the last 6 or so years, it wasn't the most beautiful game to begin with, but there's a thriving mod community with countless mods you can find to improve and/or change the game. The vanilla experience is still very enjoyable. Upon the time of writing this reviwe my Steam account has logged a 30-something hours, still rising as I'm playing through Awakening, but in my pre-PC days I must have put at least 300+ hours into this game on Xbox 360.

It has a fantastic story that you can really get yourself immersed in, plenty of GOOD QUALITY DLC, and characters you love. Playing through this game, forging relationships and alliance can be great fun and even now, on what must be my 11th (or so) playthrough of this game I've found things I've managed to miss before. It's just one of those games.

For me personally, it's a 10/10. It has it's issues but I can see past those because I just love this game (like most BioWare RPG's) so so much.
Better than Inquisition. This is a game any RPG lover should already own.

I fell in love with this game within the first few minutes. It has a great storyline to support whichever path you choose. It is also very beautiful with an amazing music score. I cannot recommend this game enough, whether you buy it on sale or not, it is worth every dollar.

An incredibly good RPG with great cutomisation, although party choice can be limited due to only having one stand-out healer if not creating one yourself. While your choice of racial origin will change little within the story it does impact it enough to make sure you know where you came from, and each major quest provides interesting, and sometime blurred moral choices. The ability to mod this game also allows for some interesting changes on multiple playthroughs, also increasing Dragon Age: Origin's vast replay value.

Want a good computer RPG that isn't too dumbed down despite being relatively new? Look no further, you've found it.

Great combat, great dialogue, good lore, some cool bosses, etc.

The only complaint I have is that the world feels somewhat instanced. It doesn't feel very open and it's split up by a lot of loading screens.

But yes, overall I will give it a 9.5. A truly amazing gem. Worth picking up if you like games like Baldur's Gate 2, Neverwinter Nights, or just want some amazing tactical combat.

There's also a good amount of mods available on the Nexus page that further improve the game, even though it's great without any mods; unlike some other RPGs (*cough* Skyrim *cough*)

Oh wow, where should I start? Well first of all this is the third time I've owned the game, first on the Xbox 360, then again on the PS3, and finally on the PC.  Now this game is dated, it came out in 2009, and you can really see it when you play it.  Even cranking the graphics up to max on your pc won't do much to improve the apperance of the game.  However there are quite a few mods out there that tweak the appearance of the game, making it signficantly more pleasant, however I have not seen any total overhaul mod out there.  Do note that there is no Steam workshop for this game, but Nexus does include the Nexus Mod Manager, and has a very large selection of mods available for this game, so definitely check them out once you buy, and install this beast.

Now for the meat of things, Dragon Age Origins is the first game in the trilogy, and takes place in Ferelden, the fictional nation inspired largely by medieval England, as the on set of the Fifth Blight encroaches the land.  I do not want to spoil anything, so I'll avoid talking any more about the story, but I feel that at this point in time almost everyone has played this game or at least wikia'd the plot.  This game features the point and click style combat, as in I left click over my oponet and he begins to swing his sword, then I can press one of my hotkeyes for him to use a skill.  Do not come in expecting this to be like DA II or DAI, where you'll be spamming the attack button like a game of Dynasty Warriors.  Fortunately you have regenerating health outside of combat, and mages have a healing branch, something that Bioware took out of DAI, which drove me insane, especially on Hard and Nightmare difficulties.  In this game you'll often find yourself pausing combat so you can survey the battlefield, formulate  a plan, and then issue orders, then unpause to watch your four man/woman team move out.

Now I would definitely recommend playing this game on hard at least, to get a real challenge out of things, it definitely makes the game more enjoyable, and I practically live in pause mode/tactical mode.  The mechanics here are amazing, as you travel from area to area, you have a slight ability to explore each of these areas.  Now this is not a free roaming game, well not in the traditional sense at least.  You can control to which 'area' you want to go to, and within each area there is a small degree of exploration involved, but to me that was never important, seeing as how I was so engrossed by the story.  There's plenty of NPC's to talk to, a fair amount of side quests to do, and so much ♥♥♥♥ to pick up it isn't even remotely funny.

The Ultimate Edition also comes with all the DLC you could ever want, and the game has for that matter.  So you definitely get your money's worth, especially with the story expansion Awakening installed that (can) continue your journey after the completition of Origins.  Not to mention you have all of the smaller story/mission DLC's to play, that will take up a few hours of your time, answer some of your questions or give you some closure in some of them, as well as net you new items for your main game.  Oh yeah I forgot about the prologue story for Leliana, entitled Leliana's Song, which takes place before Origins, lets you play as Leliana, and also gets you some cool items to use in Origins (especially for Leliana!).

This game is amazing, it has so much content, gameplay is fantastic, the story will keep you hooked and playing until the sun comes back up, and you'll know why this game is the best of the trilogy.  Plus you'll establish such unhealthy connections with some of the characters you might end up getting a body pillo...uh you'll just try to learn everything about them.  Also the game gets better with mods, they're like swear words and spices, it makes things better.  Plus it'll help clean up the appearance of the game a little bit.  Personally I love this game, it's in my top 5 games of all times, and it's better then those other two, and it has a better ending than Mass Effect 3.  This game is a 10/10, you wont find a better game with as much content for this price with access to thousands of mods that make it even better.  Plus it has a story better then the entire Elder Scrolls universe.

Even Commander Shepard would tell you that this is his favorite game on all of Steam, I mean at least believe him, he is the first human SPECTRE, savior of the galaxy, human icon, and an all around great guy.

I heavily heavily HEAVILY recommend Dragon Age: Origins and Awakening.

Origins is the first original game. Awakening is an expansion of Origins.

It's a single player rpg, and it deals with a few concepts that really interest me. Namely limited xp. By limited, I mean that once you kill bad guys in an area, they're not going to respawn. Once they're dead, they're dead. So the game encourages you to go to every side quest to get xp and other sundry, because there is NO grinding to be done.

If there is no grinding and if side quests are a big way to making xp, then it's on the developers to ensure that the quests are worth your time. Especially since there are a lot of side quests.

They do this phenomenally. Every side quest leads into something. You're not just completing a bunch of filler. You play a pivotal role in the development of others, or it's something funny, or it's kind of heartbreaking.

There are achievements that don't mean anything, of course, but they're not a massive challenge to get, and you don't have to feel like it takes too long to get them. Or that you need to reset your game to get one.

Every origin story feels unique, crafted for your race and your gender. Which means there's a lot of changed dialogue, so you don't feel like you're playing the same ♥♥♥♥ over and over again. This is especially important for the romance options. Two of them are bisexuals (they exist!), while two are straight.

While the game exists on Xbox and PS3, I play it on the PC. Which means it's open to modding, which is wonderfully simple. There's also a good deal of mods to choose from.

The graphics are pretty damn excellent for 2009 for Origins, and they get better in Awakenings.

Plot: You get to go out and recruit people to help slaughter Darkspawn. Think demons and all that. Which means you get to learn about their culture and make decisions that will influence and mold them. You can even have yourself a genocide if you're particularly evil.

See, that's the beauty of the game. You can be good, evil, or neutral, or both. And your decisions actually do effect events. Not only in your original game, but you can also import your character to Awakenings and to DA: II. If you do that, all the choices you made in the previous game will affect the other two.


Cons: Not really much of a con. One event in the Deep Roads can be a little triggering, but this part of the game is meant to be disturbing.

On the character creation scene, you see that hey, men and women are equal. Like a woman can hold a big ♥♥♥ sword same as a man. It's a common thing in these sorts of games.

But it also doesn't hold true. In WoW, males and females are treated equally. You get treated the same regardless of gender by all NPCs. Short of someone calling you pretty if you're a female, and that's just one guy.

But in Dragon Age, yeah, there's a lot of misconceptions. It's medieval, it's fantasy, it's girls should be in the home sort of thing. People are more inclined to see males as rulers, etc.

You get introduced to something triggering in two of the origin scenes. The noble dwarf, when playing a female, you get told that your enemy's friends will do things to you. And in the city elf origin, your cousin ends up gangbanged when you can't do anything to stop it.

On the other hand, that's what this game does well. It makes you feel things. Either sadness, horror, or relief. We feel for the NPCs. It's so easy to care for your companions. To want them to cheer up. To want them to like YOU.

Or if you're playing evil, it's fun to also kill them.

DA:O is my absolute favourite not only RPG game but overall RPG series. Some people may find the graphics of this first game a little outdated (though I believe there are online patches available if you're really that bothered), but other than that I would argue it's an essentially flawless experience. As long as you don't overly dislike fairly closed-world games or the occasional use of strategy in battle, there's not much else to complain about. Even if you do dislike those things, though, I'd still encourage you to give the game a chance and maybe watch some playthroughs on YouTube, just because the DA franchise gaming experience is largely unique compared to all the other games I've personally played.\nI think the greatest appeal of this game is the construction of the narrative. The story is deeply engrossing and involved, with each one of your actions and decisions both in gameplay and dialogue actually changing something about the world and plot. The origins (hA) you pick for your character also change not only other character's treatment of you and the skills you have available, but even the sympathies you yourself begin to hold in relation to the complex world and politics of Thedas. And, of course your role is to save that entire world, so the decisions you make send shockwaves of consequence throughout the entire game but, hey, no big deal.\nThe UE version of this game is an excellent price for not only the long core game itself but also all the available DLCs that are included in this pack. That said, I'd still wait for a sale on the game, just because it's on sale fairly often. If you enjoy RPGs, you should be pretty damn delighted with the rich and complex experience DA:O game offers, and are bound to return to its world for later installments as well.
Great RPG game one of the best out there! The DA Series* all of them are great.

If you enjoy rpgs driven by story and the choices you make having an impact I recommend  this game for you! This game has a multiple companions that can either love or hate you based on your decisions. Also many of your decisions impact the world in some way or another. The overarching story is seen as generic by some and in someways it is, but it is still a very good story. On the combat side of things this game has party based combat in the style of Baldur's gate where you compose a party consisting of you and 3 companions of your choice.  I would recommend getting the ultimate edition over the regular edition because the awakening expansion is very enjoyable. The other dlcs also add to the game and are fun aswell.  You will get many hours of enjoyment out of this game, not only is one playthrough long but there is a lot of replayability due to how many class combinations and decisions you can make. So overall I think this game is well worth the 30 dollar price tag but it is a good decision to wait for a sale as it usually drops to around 7 dollars which is an amazing price for how great this game is. I would give it a 9/10.

I just got done with my first replay of this game since it was released on the xbox 360, and I have to say I'm glad I decided to do a 360 and come back to replay this game.

The story for this game (side quests included) are all phenomenal! It is very immersive and I really felt (through the choices you make throughout the game) that this was MY story to live out. The voice acting and personalities of your companions are wonderful, and I can really see the replay value this game holds. Although I might not replay it for a while.

The graphics are a bit dated, but can certainly be overlooked. This was not a negative for me, I thought the game aged quite well.

The gameplay can become repetative, especially if you're on an easier difficulty. If you choose to increase the diffuculty the game gets much more strategic and much less forgiving!
It has a very classic dungeons and dragons feel with the combat, although it is not a turn based game. You can pause at any time to select abilites from any companion, or take direct control.

This is a Bioware game, so if you are not prepared for A LOT of dialog and reading, I might venture to say this is not the game for you. With that said, I enjoyed reading every bit of it. Even the little notes you find in caves or chests as you search rooms. Sometimes pages or notes found become combined to create a story (or quest) once all have been collected. I really enjoyed searching for them.

The only real pet peeve I had with this game is the lack of a storage container! Unless you buy the DLC there is no where to store your treasures. Which makes inventory management a great hassle!! Especially when I love collecting armor sets and weapons.

I did encounter a few bugs, nothing game breaking.

Buy this game, and save often. If not, just to see possible outcomes you hadn't choosen.
So much fun to play, I really enjoy it.

This is without a doubt, one of the best RPG i've ever played. I like the kind of games where you actually have an impact on the world, and this game does exactly that. Also the game adapts to what kind of character you are, meaning that you'll have some different dialog options depending on your race and gender. Six possible stories to introduce your character. It also not too linear, you can choose in which order you want to complete certain section of the game.

The mechanics are pretty simple yet you can still developp in-depth strategies. Combat is auto-attack, meaning you click on an enemy and you will keep attacking it automatically until it dies, using your abilities now and there. Not the most dynamic combat system but it worked just fine for me.The story managed to keep me interested the whole playthrought. The companions are great, thought you may feel more connections with some than others. The voice-acting is spot-on and the game offers a good challenge even on normal difficulty.

As for the DLC that come with the Ultimate edition, they have to be juged individually. Awakening is so far interesting, fun and adds to the story which is nice. Witch hunt is fun for what it adds to the story but kinda lacks challenge. Stone Prisonner adds a kickass new companion. Return to Ostagar was ok; gave good loot. Haven't tried Darkspawn Chronicles yet. Leliana's Song had an ok story but forgettable characters. Warden's Keep give a great opportunity to obtain unique loot and abilities, and gives you some sort of command base where you can store items that take too much place in your inventory. This one has a good value. And last and least, Golems of Amgarrak. I'm just going to say don't bother. It warns you that it's hard but there is a difference between hard and strait up unfair. It's also not story relevant and unrewarding.

As a whole this game is worth every penny i paid for it. If you like RPG with a deep lore, a good adaptable story, unique companions and awesome combat, pick this one up and give it a try.
You get to be a grey warden killing dark spawn, ogres, evil magic trees and the arch demon. Did I mention Ogres? But seriously whats not to like. Get it!

The story keeps a nice pace that doesn't leave you tired (except Orzammar; that started getting a little old), and has an ending that gives you some real choices that change the outcome dramatically.  The DLC for this game (comes with Ultimate, no need to purchase) is equally as well done and equally as engaging, with some nice rewards.

Combat may be my biggest gripe in this game, but there are enough abilities to keep it feeling fresh for a while.  Zooming all the way out to make it a top-down strategy RPG helped the experience dramatically, but by the end of the game, I'd felt it started to get a little long in the tooth.  The animations are somewhat lacking, however, which can sometimes make combat boring to watch.  Managing healing and stamina/mana expenditure usually will keep you pretty engaged, however.

All in all, I think Dragon Age is a great example of Bioware's quality and commitment to their product during their highest point.  I hope that their games in the future will return to this level of fidelity and aesthetic, and continue to engage the player on multiple levels.

One of the best RPGs I have ever played. Story is great, character development is spot on and decisions you make have consequences later on. I remember buying the DLC at full price and still not feeling ripped off. Really good game!

I bought this game back in 2009 on xbox when it first came out. I didn't know all that much about it, I just thought it looked interesting. I'm glad I decided to buy because it's one of the best RPGs I've ever played. I put over 100 hours into the gme when I had it for xbox.

Now a days I'm a PC gamer and when I saw Origins on sale for only $7 with ALL the DLC, I just had to get it. I have to say the PC version is a step up from the console version. Not only does it look and control better, but there are a ton of awesome mods you can install to improve the game or just add more content. The conversation system is great and really engaging. The story is pretty interesting and theres a ton of lore around it. And the battle system is a good mix between real time action and micromanagement. You can choose to play tactically by pausing the action and planning your attack or you can just run in hacking and slashing.

I could go on for days about how great this game is but honestly If you like RPG games with a lot of loot, a challenge and a great story then you'll love Origins.

In my humble opinion DA:O is the finest single player RPG ever made, by a mile. Some avid RPG gamers would point to Planescape:Torment or Baldur's Gate II as holding this accolade, and they would be right to, but DA:O is a modern game, and that gives it a technological edge (perhaps unfairly).
The story is captivating right from the outset. Racism, treachery, and evil is prevalent amongst the Dwarves, Elves and Humans - no-one can be trusted. The tragedy of war and death is vivid, as in the initial scenes where Darkspawn attack a village and an innocent woman is shown running and cut down by their blades. NPC heroes come and go - and Bioware aren't afraid of occasionally killing one of them off in the cruelest way (Walking Dead style).

The interface is a joy to use - music and effects compliment the story and settings beautifully.

The battles are great fun! If you are hardcore like I try to be you can turn off all the battle tactics and manually queue up your individual party orders, taking time to pause at least every 0.5 seconds to constantly ascertain your progress. Because of this, some battles, especially the early Revenants, take bloody ages! But it's all so action-packed and spectacularly drawn you don't really notice the minutes ticking away.

My advice to newcomers to the genre, take your time in the first few areas. Learn the basics, make choices based on your gut, and just take in the story. You will be rewarded with an experience that will last weeks and months to come.

I played about 150 hours of this when it first came out, and last week I snapped up a copy of the Ultimate Edition. What a bargain! All of the DLCs and patches in one place, so it gives me a chance to expand my adventures.

One word of caution - I run Windows 8 (no service pack) and have a fairly standard setup. It took me about 2 hours to get this game running because of the Origin Client (What is EA Games doing to PC Gaming - please stop it). My advice is check the Steam forums and Google to find your particular workaround, but I would recommend:
1. Download, install and run the game from Steam just as far as the menu.
2. Exit, uninstall Origin client
3. Download latest Origin client.
4. Activate game through Origin using your Steam CD-keys
5. Log into Origin and then run DA:O directly from Origin client
6. Log into EA games from the main DA:O menu using your Origin credentials.

After this I don't need to run the Origin client when running the game.

You can also enable a developer console to enter console commands by editing C:\Program Files (x86)\Steam\SteamApps\common\Dragon Age Ultimate Edition\data\DAOriginsLauncher.xml

Just replace the line

<true action=execute" file="${BINARIES_DIR}\DAOrigins.exe" path="${BINARIES_DIR}" autoquit="true" />

with

<true action="execute" file="${BINARIES_DIR}\DAOrigins.exe" path="${BINARIES_DIR}" autoquit="true" arguments="-enabledeveloperconsole" />
___________________________________________________________

NOTE: Some guides I found had the arguments="-enabledeveloperconsole"  before autoquit="true"
date:
but that didn't work for me.  A guide on steam listed it after and when I tried that it worked.
___________________

Then edit your Documents\BioWare\Dragon Age\Settings\KeyBindings.ini

and change the

OpenConsole_0
line to something else
recommended:
for example

OpenConsole_0=Keyboard::Button_F7

So when you press F7 it will open the developer console.
___________________

Then you can do all kinds of things with the developer console; like god mode
hoursPlayed: add any amount of money or skill points
voteText: jump to any point in the game
helpfulPercent: add or remove characters
votesHelpful:
etc..

There's a list of the commands you can use if you scroll down a bit on the wiki
http://dragonage.wikia.com/wiki/Console_%28Origins%29#

If you do this
votesTotal: make sure to use the mod to make the commands visable while you type them.  It's a lot easier that way.\n\nhttp://www.nexusmods.com/dragonage/mods/1110/"

A splendid, pure RPG experience which does not shy away from putting the player in an uncomfortable place in order to make a better story. Tactical combat is refreshing compared to the usual shooters, upgrading gear is fun as heck, the world is as living as the one around me, I fell in love with the characters and couldn't get enough of them.

The prize-content -ratio is INSANE, this is definitely a 100+ hours experience if you're interested in the sidequests and exploring the world, and in a game like this, why wouldn't you be?

There is frustration too though; the difficulty spikes are enraging and you might want to tone done the difficulty in some areas. Graphics are dated compared to modern games, but the game still has it's own unique style that holds really well.

It's game that I both loved and hated for pulling my heartstrings and that's pretty much the highest compliment I can give.

I'm not sure why it took me so long to get into this game before, but it was certainly worth the effort to do it this time around.

The story is old Bioware quality with as many engaging characters as you'd like, ready to be invested in and loved or hated.  The story keeps a nice pace that doesn't leave you tired (except Orzammar; that started getting a little old), and has an ending that gives you some real choices that change the outcome dramatically.  The DLC for this game (comes with Ultimate, no need to purchase) is equally as well done and equally as engaging, with some nice rewards.

Combat may be my biggest gripe in this game, but there are enough abilities to keep it feeling fresh for a while.  Zooming all the way out to make it a top-down strategy RPG helped the experience dramatically, but by the end of the game, I'd felt it started to get a little long in the tooth.  The animations are somewhat lacking, however, which can sometimes make combat boring to watch.  Managing healing and stamina/mana expenditure usually will keep you pretty engaged, however.

All in all, I think Dragon Age is a great example of Bioware's quality and commitment to their product during their highest point.  I hope that their games in the future will return to this level of fidelity and aesthetic, and continue to engage the player on multiple levels.

The only negative is that there appears to be a slow memory leak which is most notable lower-end machines. It's not crippling like other games which have a memory leak and is easily setback by re-starting the game every few hours, like when you go get a cup of coffee, or food.

I highly recommend Dragon Age if you are a fan of the work the Bioware does, or if you love RPG's. This is definetly one of those games you will remember for quite a long time.

I heavily heavily HEAVILY recommend Dragon Age: Origins and Awakening.

Origins is the first original game. Awakening is an expansion of Origins.

It's a single player rpg, and it deals with a few concepts that really interest me. Namely limited xp. By limited, I mean that once you kill bad guys in an area, they're not going to respawn. Once they're dead, they're dead. So the game encourages you to go to every side quest to get xp and other sundry, because there is NO grinding to be done.

If there is no grinding and if side quests are a big way to making xp, then it's on the developers to ensure that the quests are worth your time. Especially since there are a lot of side quests.

They do this phenomenally. Every side quest leads into something. You're not just completing a bunch of filler. You play a pivotal role in the development of others, or it's something funny, or it's kind of heartbreaking.

There are achievements that don't mean anything, of course, but they're not a massive challenge to get, and you don't have to feel like it takes too long to get them. Or that you need to reset your game to get one.

Every origin story feels unique, crafted for your race and your gender. Which means there's a lot of changed dialogue, so you don't feel like you're playing the same ♥♥♥♥ over and over again. This is especially important for the romance options. Two of them are bisexuals (they exist!), while two are straight.

While the game exists on Xbox and PS3, I play it on the PC. Which means it's open to modding, which is wonderfully simple. There's also a good deal of mods to choose from.

The graphics are pretty damn excellent for 2009 for Origins, and they get better in Awakenings.

Plot: You get to go out and recruit people to help slaughter Darkspawn. Think demons and all that. Which means you get to learn about their culture and make decisions that will influence and mold them. You can even have yourself a genocide if you're particularly evil.

See, that's the beauty of the game. You can be good, evil, or neutral, or both. And your decisions actually do effect events. Not only in your original game, but you can also import your character to Awakenings and to DA: II. If you do that, all the choices you made in the previous game will affect the other two.


Cons: Not really much of a con. One event in the Deep Roads can be a little triggering, but this part of the game is meant to be disturbing.

On the character creation scene, you see that hey, men and women are equal. Like a woman can hold a big ♥♥♥ sword same as a man. It's a common thing in these sorts of games.

But it also doesn't hold true. In WoW, males and females are treated equally. You get treated the same regardless of gender by all NPCs. Short of someone calling you pretty if you're a female, and that's just one guy.

But in Dragon Age, yeah, there's a lot of misconceptions. It's medieval, it's fantasy, it's girls should be in the home sort of thing. People are more inclined to see males as rulers, etc.

You get introduced to something triggering in two of the origin scenes. The noble dwarf, when playing a female, you get told that your enemy's friends will do things to you. And in the city elf origin, your cousin ends up gangbanged when you can't do anything to stop it.

On the other hand, that's what this game does well. It makes you feel things. Either sadness, horror, or relief. We feel for the NPCs. It's so easy to care for your companions. To want them to cheer up. To want them to like YOU.

Or if you're playing evil, it's fun to also kill them.

The Dragon Age series is one of the best series I've played so far. I seriously recommend the three games in the trilogy. The characters are absolutely amazing, the story is very interesting, and the entire experience is unforgettable.

Overall, I would reccommend Dragon Age: Origins to anyone looking for a lengthy and fun to play RPG campaign.

First off, I'll start with some of the negatives. Graphically, the game isn't really much to look at compared to what one might be used to in this day and age of graphics and content; it's an older game, so I should hope prospective buyers can easily overlook this. Secondly, the game does have a tendency to crash (at least on my computer) if too much is going on at one time, but with the ever frequent autosaves and a hopefully attentive-in-saving player, this shouldn't prove too much of an issue. Finally, there is quite a difficulty curve, even on normal difficulty settings. Do not expect a quick walk through the part to overpowered status like in a round of Skyrim; if you don't learn to utilize strategy and your companions, you aren't going to get very far. Luckily, if you are feeling a bit overwhelmed, difficulty can be changed at any time from the in-game options menu, though I would suggest struggling through the campaign on at least normal difficulty for satisfying payoff.

For the most part, that's really all the issues I can find at this particular moment. There may be more, I just can't think of them! So, let's get to the good stuff. One might expect Dragon Age: Origins to be like Mass Effect but in the Middle Ages" because of the pedigree associated with it. There are certainly some aspects of Dragon Age: Origins that one may find similar to its developer's previous titles
recommended: it's unique from both its predecessors and other big-name RPGs.\n\nIn terms of gameplay

reviewText:
One of my favorit RPG's out there, you get to chose from 3 different races, Human, Dwarf and 2 different types of Elf's, The Dalish (wood elf's) and City Elf's (Elf who are living in the human city slums).
After you get to chose their Origin, this can differ from being a Noble born, or being a born of a lower class, each has it's effect on the story you play, and the game, giving a great reason to replay the game multiple times.
You then chose a class, you can pick 1 out of 3 choices, Warriro, rogue and mage, but this does not mean you have to be fx, a warrior with a sword and shield, you get to chose how you want to play your class, and what role you want to be in your group, of up to 4 members at a time.

The combat is real time, with a pause function so you can select a individual hero / companion and make them do a precise action. This makes gives the combat alot of strategy, and makes it alot of fun.
The leveling up system is pretty standart, you get to assing points into Strenght, Endurance, Willpower and so on, pretty standart from other RPG's.

Through out the game you will meet different companions, and you get to make your own group as you see fit. This brings up the strategy again, you can make your group as you see fit, you can go all berzerk and go with 4 damage dealers, or you can even it all out, and have a tank, healer and 2 damage dealers, kinda like you own little WoW dungeon group.
One neat feature is you get to have actual conversations with them, and they have different personalitys, and you can earn affection points with each and every one of them. At some point's, your companions will even backstap you, if they don't like you enough.

The story in the game is great, you are a Grey Warden, the defenders of the Realm against the Dark Spawn. A race made up of monsters, demons and all that evil ♥♥♥♥, who is led by the Arch Demon ( A giant ♥♥♥ dragon ! ), you have to help the realm by gathering an army from different factions through the world, to fight the Dark Spawn horde, els all will be lost.
Im not going to say much more on the story, but it is one of the best features of this game. The very best being YOU GET TO DECIDE HOW ITS ALL GOING TO PLAY OUT, your choices matter in the game, and will have consequenses later on.

Over all DA:O is a great time, there is so much to do, and you get hundres of hours worth of gameplay. The main game is fantastic, and I'd surgest only getting the DLC if you really like the game, but even the DLC is worth it. They give you a good 3-5 hours worth of content, maybe abit more. Overall the DLC is cool, buy them if you like the game, they are like springels on a already awesome Sunday Ice Cream.

Now the expansion on the other hand, is not really worth it. The story is pretty boring, it ends just as it gets interesting, and it dosnt really feel as epic, as the standart game does. The Story starts a few months after completing the main games story, you are now the Grey Warden commander, and you have to remake the Grey Wardens, by getting new people to become Grey Wardens, as said it sounds pretty cool, but in the end it is a very boring story and kind of lazy written. It's just not as good as the main story.
The Expansion got some cool features, like cool looking armors, a new level cap, and some other nice things.
Sure it's some hours worth of gameplay, but overall id say it's not really worth it. It feels tagged on and I would only recomend it, if you can get your hands on the Dragon Age : Origins - Ultimate Edition.

I enjoyed the hell out of DA:O - Ultimate Edition, and I would highly recommend this game to anyone who likes RPG's.
Simply an Awesome game by any means. Any player of single play will enjoy this great RPG.

Definitely a recommended game.\n\nSmooth gameplay. Decent visuals based on date of release. Compelling storyline with deep lore/history and great characters.  Oh and with the Ultimate Edition, LOTS of content.

With the massive success of this game and the latest, Dragon Age Inquisition, BioWare has made this game and that game very fun and so much content. But Dragon Age 2 was lacking the immersion and feel that is in this one. I hope you consider this game. This game is so long that you have to make several breaks to get all the way through the game. Please get this game because it is that fun.

This game is one of the best RPG's in existence. It has a diverse cast of characters, each with their own unique look and personality. As the main character, you get to pick your race (human, dwarf, or elf), completely customize your appearence and skill set, and choose between several origin stories (hence the name of the game) for your character. Based on what you choose, NPC's have different reactions towards you. You can also recruit many companions throughout your travels, each packaged with their own backstory and personal quests. The voice acting in the game is pretty amazing. Each companion and major plot line character has a voice that is unique to them and easily recognizable.

Gameplay is great as well. While on easier difficulties, you can take whoever you want with you, click on an enemy, and easily win, it is far more complex on higher difficulties. The game uses a tactics system that makes your companions use their abilities to react to certain conditions. On a high difficulty, it is necessary to balance out your companions abilities and tactics to ensure that you will be ready for even the strongest of enemies. If you don't have good balance or don't plan your battles, you will likely be easily destroyed.

As far as graphics go, I will admit that this game isn't the best looking (but hey, it's five years old now, so it's pretty easy to overlook, and the other aspects of the game more than make up for it). However, Bioware has made this game easily moddable so there are many mods out there that can completely transform this game. I don't even know how many I have installed, but it's a lot!

Overall, this game is just a fantastic RPG with decent graphics, great story, unique characters, amazing voice acting, complex gameplay, and an amazing modding community. If you like RPGs and haven't played this yet,  THEN GET OFF YOUR BUTT AND GET THIS GAME.
One of the best RPG games of all time, any gaming fan NEEDS to play this, and PC is the perfect platform for this masterpiece.

Disappointingly, not a heartwarming coming-of-age story about a young dragon learning their way in the world.  However, still quite entertaining, as there are multiple dragons, despite the fact that the player is forced to murder them without even hearing their point of view.  Compared with other games which have zero dragons, however, this is miles better.  3/5 dragons.
I romanced a hot elf and then I died riding a dragon which is really how I want my real life to go

This game was like a great book you just can't put down until you finish. And when it did finish I was left satisfied yet wanting more. A truly immersive experience, I found myself talking to my companions, and laughing at their bickering. It features a great storyline with a different outcome depending on your choices. There is a bit of a morale system in that certain companions will like or dislike your actions and you will gain or lose reputation with them. Some companions have different morals than others so you can choose to take those who will agree with your choices and thus gain rep with them. However for the most part you'll want to choose your companions based on what classes/spells you need for battles. This game can be brutally hard with battles, but it does have a difficulty option which can be changed at any time.

If you're a fan of RPG's this is a must-play. It features immersive towns and people, all of which have something to do or say. The world is full and rich, with no empty" spots.

However
recommended: so if you skip something you may not be able to go back later if you go forward in the main quest. Side quests are aplenty as are companions. You may struggle with bag space as you never know what you might need. I got around this by avoiding the crafting specialisations and selling the materials. This left room for all the loot.\n\nAll in all
hoursPlayed: I'd give this a 9.5/10. Very few RPG's come close to this immersive experience."

reviewText: I have recently been revisiting this little gem that I once owned on Xbox 360. I wish I'd had the PC version from the start! The controls are so much better, having hotbars to put skills in is great, and the game looks very nice on PC. For those of you who havent played this, or have only played it on Xbox, I'd recommend buying it (on sale right now $7.99). The DLCs are worth the investment, and the game still keeps me captivated even though I've probably beaten it on Xbox 3 or 4 times.\n\nThose who haven't played Dragon Age can expect an awesome RPG with tons of character customization, interaction between party members, and of course thrilling and challenging combat. If you liked Baldur's Gate, Neverwinter Nights, and Icewind Dale, this is the type of game for you. (minus the D&D rules, but it still follows the basic recipe for a great party-based RPG.) Definitely a good buy at the price!!

Firstly the pictures of 'gameplay' on the store page are LIES. The game is set is a 'tactical' view which is similar to the views in games like balders gate of others. this however, instead of ruining the game, improves it. The storyline is intresting and as the game progresses you get to know your party as well. Basicaly if you like a change from games like skyrim then get this game.
One of the single best games I've ever played in my life. Fantastic story, interesting characters and satisfying gameplay, would reccomend to anyone who enjoys a good story. Even better with mods.
Dragon Age: Origins is a RPG that relies heavily on good strategy and tactics to overcome enemies. The story is very deep and the characters are amusing. Get this game now!

One of my favourite games to date, if not my favourite ever.

Dragon Age: Origins allows you to make decisions and interact with NPCs and party members in a way that can get you truly attached to their stories. There are so many tales woven into one wonderful, complete and complex campaign which you can, to a fair extent, influence through your decisions. The combat system is very simple to learn but still can be manipulated to fit your style, and you can make this game as challenging or leisurely as you like it.

Not only can I appraise the obvious, but I can also comfortably say that the attention to detail in this game, right down to the little things like the designs on the armour sets, is set to a very high standard.

It's abundantly clear how much work was poured into this game. The only flaw I could accentuate would be that the dungeon crawling does get a tad repetitive, but it's necessary, so if you can forsake a hard. gruelling dungeon crawl and you're willing to give up many, many hours of your life, this game comes with my strongest recommendation.

I am currently playing through the game with 3 different characters, and have already beaten it once. Awakening is pretty good, I like the new characters and the story is interesting, and is a good ride as well. The only dlc I have played is Darkspawn Chronicles which has been a hell of a lot of fun running through humans as an ogre. If you like rpgs you need to give dragon age a try.

A story that compels you all the way through it, Dragon Age: Origins is a game crafted of brilliance. The Ultimate Edition gives you the most complete version, with some of the best DLC.
This game certainly can be challenge, but the story and combat are unique and compelling. You may end up playing it over and over again. 10/10 reccomend

Dragons Age is well a put together RPG that will immerse you in the story and you will invest time in developing the characters that accompany you on your quest. The biggest downside to the game is the story is tried, tired and done a thousand times over. You the hero are on quest to destroy the dark spawn that is wreaking havoc on the land. This being its biggest downfall does not make this a bad game at all. I had over 40+ hours in one play through and with all the decision making you encounter this game will surely keep you amused for multiple plays. One of the best combat systems I've seen you can not only setup the AI to have your companions on the quest do what you like but you can fully take control of them which in my opinion is a huge advantage. The combat system is a little bit of learning curve but once you get the hang of it you will love it and enjoy the simpleness of how your characters act and follow your directions in the heat of some best battles you will see in an RPG. Bioware did an excellent job in creating a game you can fully plunge yourself into and get behind.

It's amazing that this game still is one of the best games of its genre, if not The best.

Intriguing story, not too shabby graphics, fun and unique combat, good variety of difficulty levels, some very interesting/funny characters and, for the most part, good voice acting(something i find very rare).

The few flaws in some areas are definitely made up for by other parts of the game.
And with some mods you can improve this already amazing game even more!

A personal favorite of mine, Dragon Age: Origins is arguably much, much better than its sequel and many other games released by Bioware.  It's a very, very long RPG game whose story is told mostly in dialogue between your party members and cinematics, with a combat system that is on par with other RPGs for its time, also featuring a pause-combat tactics system to allow more control over your party members and your PC.  Because it is a Bioware game, it also includes the option to romance four of your companions, complete with separate cutscenes, achievements, and quests.  It has very high replay value with many different endings, and offers the player a chance to influence the game by their choices (it could be life or death in some cases). Your party members will also have a say in how you react to certain situations, often with witty remarks or harsh criticism. The only downside to this game that I can see, personally, is the less than stunning graphics quality of the game.  If you want graphic quality, but don't mind missing out on an amazing storyline in exchange for pretty graphics and a slightly better combat system, pick up Dragon Age 2 instead (however, I've only played the console version of DA2, and only beginning to play the PC version of DA:O).  If you want a game that could easily take you weeks to complete a single playthrough, not counting any of the DLC included with the Ultimate Edition, this is a great game for you to pick up.  I highly recommend, also, making a female warden and romancing Alistair.  Trust me, his dialogue makes the trouble worth it.

If you like Skyrim and or Guild Wars you are probably going to love this games as much as I have been.  I am still playing through and will write more later.  So much to see and do here.  A fantastic game and well worth the price.

Supremely engrossing fantasy rpg with a baller tactical combat system, memorable characters, brick ♥♥♥♥-tons of content and Bioware's best writing outside of Karpyshyn's Darth Bane novels (and his spitballing on what the ME3 ending could have been). The sequel is poopy garbage but since DA:O has more potential playtime packed into it than most games manage with entire trilogies, it's honestly not worth getting buttmad about. 11/10 basically Full Communism in videogame form.

reviewText: Addicting game worth buying on the cheap. I haven't played turn-based roleplaying games since the original release of Neverwinter Nights, but I picked this up on a sale and I can't stop thinking about it. However, coming from an RPG hiatus, the combat system needs work. Often I'm grinding mobs without strategy, and the challenge in battles is tempermental. Sometimes it's a breeze, and sometimes I'm destroyed in seconds. The learning curve for the tactics system and all the available skills can be high, but I don't discount user error. Would have loved more of an introduction or a large community focused on min-maxing tactic combinations. In all, great game. Can't wait for Inquisition.

Whether you are a seasoned rpg player or are just getting started you absolutely need to play this game. One of the best modern rpgs ever.

reviewText:
A very long, but excellent game overall. Aside from the Elder Scrolls series, I don't know any games that will give you more bang for your buck than Dragon Age (: Origins - Ultimate Edition). If you go through all the DLC and finish most of the sidequests in the game you'll easily spend over 100 hours on a single run, and there were hardly any points in the game where I felt like the plot was starting to drag.

The gameplay is good overall. I do think the strategy elements were sometimes a bit tedious though. I didn't like pausing battles every 0.5 seconds to give all of my characters new orders and it was also difficult sometimes to get my characters to do exactly what I wanted them to, when I wanted them to. The AI is not as bad as in Mass Effect 1, but I still often had to deal with things like my ranged fighter throwing herself into melee combat rather than keeping distance and my assassin attacking enemies head on rather than trying to backstab. The game does provide you with Tactics slots to tell your characters in advance how to respond to situations in battle, but that takes a lot of time to set up and doesn't always give good results.

As with most BioWare games (KOTOR, Mass Effect), they've put a lot of effort into developing the main characters and giving them intruiging backstories. However, in Dragon Age I feel like they've even taken it a few steps further. Each individual character gets lots of 'screen time' (if you bother to talk to them) and the romance sidequest has been worked out a lot more than in their previous games. One of the gameplay elements is a 'relationship' system that will make choices you make during the game affect your relationship with your party members. A good relationship will make characters befriend you or fall in love with you (revealing more of the character's backstory), a bad relationship might make the character leave the party permanently. Personally, I really loved this and wish more RPGs had this.

What I particularly loved about this game is that the choices that you face during the development of the plot aren't always as straightforward as picking a good or bad option. You will face plenty of dillemmas in which it is not so obvious what the outcome of your choices will be and you'll feel compelled to apply your own moral reasoning to the situation. In the end, this makes it feel more like you're actually playing as yourself (or a realistic human being) and not someone who's putting up a goody-two-shoes / bad-♥♥♥ act.

Anyway, I enjoyed Dragon Age a lot. I think it will please any fan of the RPG genre. It's a very well-made game overall that is more than worth the €7,50 I paid for it during the Sale.

Dragon Age Origins is a beautiful RPG game with a not-so-unique overarcing plot with many subplots sprinkled in between. The characters are alive and full of their own personality and own agendas. Great combat system, though it takes a while to get the hang of it.\n\nPlus you get a dog and you can ride into battle with him. (not on him unfortunately but that'd be cool. I'm sure a mod exists for that)

Dragon Age: Origins is a truly epic fantasy-based RPG created by Bioware. In this story you are a Grey Warden, a member of a highly-respected order comprised of Ferelden's most elite and capable warriors. It is your sworn duty as a Warden to rise up as a leader amongst the people in order to unite them against a devestating force of evil known as The Darkspawn." These creatures have dwelled in the deepest

- Solid Soundtrack/Graphics
- Tons of Replayability
- Loads of Content (60+ Hrs)
- Nightmare Mode Is An Adequate Challenge (Especially Soloing)
- Mods Mods Mods


Cons:

- A Few Bugs (Mana Clash-Crash happened to me a few times)
- Acquiring DLC can be a bit of a pain (Through Bioware Social-Network)
- Some Specializations Are Slightly Underwhelming (Shapeshifter comes to mind)
- Not Enough Freedom In Party-Selection (You must have a Rogue to pick locks
